"Kealhofer L., Huang F., DeVincenzi M., Kim M.M.",Phytoliths in Chinese foxtail millet (Setaria italica),2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,223,,,116,127,,1,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.09.004,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84945259011&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.09.004&partnerID=40&md5=cfc54157f2b92b4480f4b12bdcdfeab3,"Environmental Studies and Sciences/Anthropology Departments, Santa Clara University, Santa Clara, CA, United States; Nanjing Institute of Geology and Paleontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing, China; Anthropology Department, Santa Clara University, Santa Clara, CA, United States","Kealhofer, L., Environmental Studies and Sciences/Anthropology Departments, Santa Clara University, Santa Clara, CA, United States; Huang, F., Nanjing Institute of Geology and Paleontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing, China; DeVincenzi, M., Anthropology Department, Santa Clara University, Santa Clara, CA, United States; Kim, M.M., Anthropology Department, Santa Clara University, Santa Clara, CA, United States","Increasingly, archeologists are realizing that early agriculturalists manipulated suites of plant species as they contended with environmental instability and cultural performance. Studying these complex interactions requires robust diagnostic indicators for each species. This has been particularly difficult for millet macrobotanical remains in Asia. Microbotanical remains, such as phytoliths, offer a possible alternative for millet identification. To date, work on Setaria phytoliths has focused on a restricted number of species, limiting the confidence of identifying domesticated Setaria. Here we present the results of morphometric analysis of both leaf and inflorescence morphology across 12 of the 14 species of Setaria found in China today. Results suggest that robust discrimination of Setaria italica requires measurements of two types of inflorescence bract cells. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Agriculture; China; Foxtail millet; Microbotanical remains; Phytolith morphology,agricultural change; biogenic material; identification method; instability; leaf morphology; microbiology; millet; morphology; paleobotany; paleoenvironment; phytolith; China; Setaria (plant); Setaria faberi; Setaria italica,,,,,"SCU, Santa Clara University; XDA 05130501; CAS, Chinese Academy of Sciences","We would like to thank the staff of the Herbarium, Institute of Botany, Jiangsu Province, Chinese Academy of Sciences, for allowing us to take Setaria samples for our research. XDA 05130501 ). Santa Clara University also supported this research with grant funding. "Sun C., Taylor T.N., Na Y., Li T., Krings M.",Unusual preservation of a microthyriaceous fungus (Ascomycota) on Sphenobaiera (ginkgophyte foliage) from the Middle Jurassic of China,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,223,,,21,30,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.08.006,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84942122999&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.08.006&partnerID=40&md5=23ace3ccf3b2f1a0ff9e9753484395e2,"Key Laboratory for Evolution of Past Life and Environment in Northeast Asia, Ministry of Education, Changchun, Jilin, China; Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, And Natural History Museum and Biodiversity Research Institute, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Department für Geo- und Umweltwissenschaften, Paläontologie und Geobiologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität, And Bayerische Staatssammlung für Paläontologie und Geologie, Richard-Wagner-Straße 10, Munich, Germany; Research Center of Palaeontology and Stratigraphy, Jilin University, Changchun, Jilin, China","Sun, C., Key Laboratory for Evolution of Past Life and Environment in Northeast Asia, Ministry of Education, Changchun, Jilin, China, Research Center of Palaeontology and Stratigraphy, Jilin University, Changchun, Jilin, China; Taylor, T.N., Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, And Natural History Museum and Biodiversity Research Institute, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Na, Y., Key Laboratory for Evolution of Past Life and Environment in Northeast Asia, Ministry of Education, Changchun, Jilin, China, Research Center of Palaeontology and Stratigraphy, Jilin University, Changchun, Jilin, China; Li, T., Key Laboratory for Evolution of Past Life and Environment in Northeast Asia, Ministry of Education, Changchun, Jilin, China, Research Center of Palaeontology and Stratigraphy, Jilin University, Changchun, Jilin, China; Krings, M., Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, And Natural History Museum and Biodiversity Research Institute, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States, Department für Geo- und Umweltwissenschaften, Paläontologie und Geobiologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität, And Bayerische Staatssammlung für Paläontologie und Geologie, Richard-Wagner-Straße 10, Munich, Germany","Leaves today are inhabited by a wide variety of fungi, typically ascomycetes, but also some basidiomycetes and zygomycetes. Little is known to date regarding the fungi that colonized the leaves of fossil plants older than Cretaceous. In this paper we describe ascomycete fruiting bodies (ascomata) that are present on the adaxial surface of a Sphenobaiera (Ginkgophyta) leaf from a Middle Jurassic deposit near Daohugou village, Inner Mongolia, China. The ascomata are identified as imprints in the leaf cuticle, with only parts remaining of the actual body fossil. Fruiting bodies are scutate, spherical in outline, and consist of three distinct zones delimited by the size and arrangement of the hyphae. The morphology is suggestive of geologically younger microthyriaceous ascomata, especially Asterothyrites, Microthyriacites, and Trichothyrites. This discovery represents the oldest fossil evidence of microthyriaceous fungi inhabiting ginkgophytes. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Ascoma; Cuticle; Daohugou; Epiphyllous fungi; Ginkgophyta; Thyriothecium,colonization; foliage; fossil record; fruiting; fungus; Jurassic; morphology; paleobotany; preservation; China; Daohugou; Nei Monggol; Ascomycota; Basidiomycota; Fungi; Ginkgophyta; Sphenobaiera; Zygomycetes,,,,,"EAR-0542170, NSF, National Science Foundation; 1212011120149, CGS, China Geological Survey; 41172009, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 20100061110034, MOE, Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China","This study was supported by funds from the National Natural Science Foundation of China ( 41172009 ), the China Geological Survey ( 1212011120149 ), the Doctoral Fund of the Ministry of Education of China ( 20100061110034 ), Project ‘111’, China , and the National Science Foundation, USA ( EAR-0542170 ). "Lee G.E., Bechteler J., Schäfer-Verwimp A., Heinrichs J.","Microlejeunea miocenica sp. nov. (Porellales, Jungermanniopsida) in Dominican amber, the first fossil of a subcosmopolitan genus of leafy liverworts",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,16,21,,5,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.002,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84939814250&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.002&partnerID=40&md5=eb9f9a2833db148af8bdbde7541c6c69,"Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Department für Biologie I, Systematische Botanik und Mykologie, Geobio-Center, Menzinger Straße 67, München, Germany; Mittlere Letten 11, Herdwangen-Schönach, Germany","Lee, G.E., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Department für Biologie I, Systematische Botanik und Mykologie, Geobio-Center, Menzinger Straße 67, München, Germany; Bechteler, J., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Department für Biologie I, Systematische Botanik und Mykologie, Geobio-Center, Menzinger Straße 67, München, Germany; Schäfer-Verwimp, A., Mittlere Letten 11, Herdwangen-Schönach, Germany; Heinrichs, J., Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Department für Biologie I, Systematische Botanik und Mykologie, Geobio-Center, Menzinger Straße 67, München, Germany","We describe a lejeuneoid liverwort preserved in Miocene Dominican amber. The plants creep on bark, have zig-zagged stems, entire-margined suberect leaves with large lobules with a curved apical tooth at the free margin, small, bifid underleaves with forward-directed lobes, and winged female bracts. They are assigned to the extant genus Microlejeunea and classified as Microlejeunea miocenica sp. nov., representing the first fossil of this genus. So far 17 extant genera of Lejeuneaceae have been recognized in Dominican amber, pointing to generic stasis of the regional epiphytic diversity since the Miocene. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Bryophyte; Classification; Lejeuneaceae; Marchantiophyta; Miocene; Neogene,amber; classification; epiphyte; fossil record; liverwort; Miocene; paleobotany; species diversity; Dominica; Leeward Islands [Lesser Antilles]; bryophytes; Jungermanniopsida; Lejeuneaceae; Marchantiophyta; Microlejeunea; Porellales,,,,,Alexander von Humboldt-Stiftung,We thank Günter Bechly and Karin Wolf-Schwenninger (Museum of Natural History Stuttgart) for a loan of the investigated amber specimen. "Vincent J.H., Cwynar L.C.","Pollen whiskers, rational limits and cryptic refugia: Determining the local presence of spruce on lateglacial landscapes of eastern Canada",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,48,55,,,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.08.002,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84940394581&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.08.002&partnerID=40&md5=30b798c015f9a2e48ec390fb8395987d,"University of New Brunswick, Biology Department, P.O. Box 4400, Fredericton, NB, Canada","Vincent, J.H., University of New Brunswick, Biology Department, P.O. Box 4400, Fredericton, NB, Canada; Cwynar, L.C., University of New Brunswick, Biology Department, P.O. Box 4400, Fredericton, NB, Canada","The 20% spruce isopoll has traditionally been used to identify the range limit of spruce in eastern North America. Using plant macrofossils and stomates in a network of 25 lateglacial-aged sites throughout Nova Scotia, we identified sites where spruce was locally present but contributed as little as 4% to the pollen rain. Our data suggest that 8% pollen abundance is a more reasonable limit that consistently indicates the local presence of trees. Using 8% to define the presence of spruce, we find that the number of sites likely to contain spruce increases from 3 to 11 as compared to using the 20% isopoll. The resulting increase in the estimated distribution of spruce leads to a reduction in the apparent migration lags and migration rates of spruce into the region. Reducing the error in distribution histories will provide better-constrained estimates of climate change and its impact on the local vegetation. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Lateglacial; Macrofossil; Rational limit; Spruce; Stomates; Whisker,abundance; climate change; coniferous tree; fossil; landscape; late glacial; migration; pollen; vegetation cover; Canada; Nova Scotia; Picea,,,,,"NSERC, Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada","This research was supported by a Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council Discovery Grant to Les Cwynar. We gratefully acknowledge the helpful comments of Alwynne Beaudoin and 3 anonymous reviewers. "Sucerquia P.A., Bernardes-de-Oliveira M.E.C., Mohr B.A.R.","Phytogeographic, stratigraphic, and paleoclimatic significance of Pseudofrenelopsis capillata sp. nov. from the Lower Cretaceous Crato Formation, Brazil",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,116,128,,1,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.012,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84941117246&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.012&partnerID=40&md5=52a6ece19abb1b38c7a24cb6480a3a09,"Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, Rua do Lago 562, Cidade Universitária, São Paulo, SP, Brazil; Departamento de Geologia, Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, Avenida Academico Helio Ramos s/n, Cidade Universitaria, Recife, PE, Brazil; Museum of Natural History, Collections, Invalidenstrasse 43, Berlin, Germany","Sucerquia, P.A., Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, Rua do Lago 562, Cidade Universitária, São Paulo, SP, Brazil, Departamento de Geologia, Universidade Federal de Pernambuco, Avenida Academico Helio Ramos s/n, Cidade Universitaria, Recife, PE, Brazil; Bernardes-de-Oliveira, M.E.C., Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, Rua do Lago 562, Cidade Universitária, São Paulo, SP, Brazil; Mohr, B.A.R., Museum of Natural History, Collections, Invalidenstrasse 43, Berlin, Germany","Coniferales are represented during the Early Cretaceous in northern South America both by macrofossils and palynomorphs of the families Araucariaceae and Cheirolepidiaceae. Fossils of Cheirolepidiaceae are often abundant in coastal deposits; plants of this family are considered to have grown under semiarid to arid climate conditions because of characteristic anatomical features which include several adaptations to aridity and/or salinity. Here histologically preserved specimens of Pseudofrenelopsis from laminated limestones of the Crato Formation (Araripe Basin, NE Brazil) were studied by light and scanning electron microscopy. A new species Pseudofrenelopsis capillata sp. nov. is described which seems to have grown exclusively at the Early Cretaceous (sub)paleoequatorial area of South America and may be therefore endemic. The new taxon may have grown in a riparian environment along the borders of a large lake as a minor constituent of the surrounding vegetation. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Cheirolepidiaceae; Climate sensitivity; Crato Formation; Early Cretaceous; Histology; Pseudofrenelopsis capillata,adaptation; aridity; coniferous tree; Cretaceous; fossil record; histology; limestone; new species; paleoclimate; palynomorph; phytogeography; salinity; sensitivity analysis; stratigraphy; type specimen; Araripe Basin; Brazil; South America; Araucariaceae; Cheirolepidiaceae; Coniferales,,,,,"FAPESP 2008/02884-5, FAPESP, Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo; 304978/2013-2; 2003/09407-4; 428a, UFRJ, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro; USP, Universidade de São Paulo; AMNH, American Museum of Natural History","The authors would like to acknowledge the collaboration of Lutz Kunzmann (Senckenberg Naturhistorische Sammlungen, Dresden) for help to access the collections for comparison with previously described specimens of the Crato Formation. Cornelia Hiller and Catrin Puffert, staff members of the Museum of Natural History Berlin (MfN, Berlin), supported the curatorial handling of the Berlin specimens. Thanks to Dr. Isaac Jamil Sayeg for support in the SEM examination at the Instituto de Geociências (Universidade de São Paulo) and also to Dr. Ismar de Souza Carvalho (Instituto de Geociências, Universidade Federal de Rio de Janeiro) for the loan of the specimen UFRJ Pb 428a. John Wingerath (Paleobotany Collections of the American Museum of Natural History, Washington) was so kind to provide access to North American and English specimens and mounted cuticles. We also would like to thank to Dr. Brian Axsmith (University of South Alabama, Mobile) for the possibility to study North American vegetative and reproductive specimens and for the supply of cuticular material for detailed comparisons. The first author would like to acknowledge the financial support for a scholarship and research funds provided by the Fundação de Amparo a Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo ( FAPESP 2008/02884-5 ). Szafer Institute of Botany, Polish Academy of Sciences, Lubicz 46, Kraków, Poland; Kołaczek, P., Department of Biogeography and Palaeoecology, Faculty of Geographical and Geological Sciences, Adam Mickiewicz University, Dziegielowa 27, Poznań, Poland; Jankovská, V., Department of Vegetation Ecology, Institute of Botany, Czech Academy of Sciences, Lidická 25/27, Brno, Czech Republic; Turner, F., Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Building 3, Courtyard 16, Lincui Road, Chaoyang District, Beijing, China; Karpińska-Kołaczek, M., Department of Biogeography and Palaeoecology, Faculty of Geographical and Geological Sciences, Adam Mickiewicz University, Dziegielowa 27, Poznań, Poland, Department of Palaeobotany and Palaeoherbarium, Institute of Botany, Jagiellonian University, Lubicz 46, Kraków, Poland, Laboratory of Wetland Ecology and Monitoring, Faculty of Geographical and Geological Sciences, Adam Mickiewicz University, Dziegielowa 27, Poznań, Poland; Pini, R., CNR - Institute for the Dynamics of Environmental Processes, Laboratory of Palynology and Palaeoecology, Piazza della Scienza 1, Milano, Italy; Pedziszewska, A., Laboratory of Palaeoecology and Archaeobotany, Department of Plant Ecology, University of Gdańsk, Wita Stwosza 59, Gdańsk, Poland; Zimny, M., Laboratory of Palaeoecology and Archaeobotany, Department of Plant Ecology, University of Gdańsk, Wita Stwosza 59, Gdańsk, Poland; Stivrins, N., Institute of Geology, Tallinn University of Technology, Ehitajate tee 5, Tallinn, Estonia, Department of Geosciences and Geography, University of Helsinki, PO BOX 64, Helsinki, Finland; Szymczyk, A., Department of Physical Geography, Faculty of Earth Sciences, University of Silesia, Bedzińska 60, Sosnowiec, Poland","This paper describes specimens of Pediastrum argentinense-type in Late Quaternary sediments, focusing on their morphological variability and stressing their value for palaeobotanical studies. Although the taxon strongly resembles P. argentinense Bourrelly et Tell in Tell, known only from South America, some morphological differences between P. argentinense and P. argentinense-type lead to the conclusion that we are dealing with a separate taxon provisionally named P. argentinense-type. To make its taxonomic position clear, there is a need for detailed morphological observations of living specimens and molecular analyses. This taxon was found in sections spanning the entire Late Glacial and Holocene periods across Central Europe. Its affinity to sediments originating in shallow and strongly overgrown water bodies makes it a good indicator of such conditions in past environments. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Holocene; Late Glacial; Palaeobioindicator; Pediastrum; Subfossil algae,bioindicator; green alga; Holocene; Last Glacial; molecular analysis; morphology; paleoecology; paleoenvironment; palynology; taxonomy; Europe; algae; Pediastrum,,,,,"4/2015, PAN, Polska Akademia Nauk; RVO 67985939, AV ČR, Akademie Věd České Republiky; 2013Y2ZB0001; N N305 063739; N 307 062 32/3359; 206/09/1504; ETF9031; Hosei University","The authors are grateful to Yuuji Tsukii, Hosei University (Tokyo, Japan) for giving his permission to print Pediastrum argentinense photomicrographs. "Bashforth A.R., Nelson W.J.","A Middle Pennsylvanian macrofloral assemblage from below the Rock Island (No. 1) Coal Member, Illinois: Resolving the Bolsovian-Asturian boundary in the Illinois Basin",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,67,83,,6,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.003,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84940369590&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.003&partnerID=40&md5=0057325527aae926c7136a6392796b9a,"Illinois State Geological Survey, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, 615 East Peabody Drive, Champaign, IL, United States; Department of Paleobiology, National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, DC, United States","Bashforth, A.R., Illinois State Geological Survey, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, 615 East Peabody Drive, Champaign, IL, United States, Department of Paleobiology, National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, DC, United States; Nelson, W.J., Illinois State Geological Survey, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, 615 East Peabody Drive, Champaign, IL, United States","A taxonomic, quantitative, and biostratigraphic analysis is presented for a macrofloral assemblage collected from below the Rock Island (No. 1) Coal Member at the historical Friendship Farm locality in Rock Island County, on the northwestern margin of the Illinois Basin. The Middle Pennsylvanian (middle Moscovian) fossiliferous strata involve the middle Tradewater Formation, and are situated a short distance below the Atokan-Desmoinesian Stage boundary as defined by marine microfossils and palynology. The assemblage of 14 fossil-taxa is overwhelmingly dominated by pteridosperms, including Laveineopteris rarinervis, Neuropteris flexuosa, Alethopteris serlii, Macroneuropteris scheuchzeri, and Mariopteris nervosa, whereas lycopsids, sphenopsids, and ferns are comparatively rare. Homotaxial comparison with the macrofloral biozonation scheme established in Europe indicates an Asturian age for the assemblage, in all likelihood early Asturian (Linopteris obliqua Biozone). Similar comparisons with range limits documented in the Appalachian Basin yield a more ambiguous age, but an early Asturian age is equally probable. These findings indicate that the Bolsovian-Asturian Substage boundary of western Europe lies below the Atokan-Desmoinesian Stage boundary in the Illinois Basin, boundaries that have traditionally been correlated by palynology. The Middle Pennsylvanian interval near these boundaries is being increasingly recognized as one of significant environmental change, reflected in marked lithological and biological modifications throughout tropical Euramerica. However, the fact that the Bolsovian-Asturian and Atokan-Desmoinesian boundaries are not synchronous, albeit being broadly equivalent, suggests that the environmental perturbation was a protracted event that may have had global consequences. © 2015.",Asturian; Atokan; Biostratigraphy; Bolsovian; Desmoinesian; Macroflora,biostratigraphy; biozonation; Carboniferous; fern; flora; fossil record; marine environment; palynology; Pennsylvanian; taxonomy; Appalachian Basin; Europe; Illinois; Illinois Basin; Rock Island County; United States; Alethopteris; Filicophyta; Laveineopteris rarinervis; Lycopodiopsida; Mariopteris; Neuropteris; Sphenopsida,,,,,"SI, Smithsonian Institution; NMNH, National Museum of Natural History; Paleontological Society; ARB, California Air Resources Board","This project would not have happened without the continued support of William A. DiMichele at the National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution , which initially funded the Visiting Researcher posting of ARB at the ISGS. Prolongation of the temporary stay was made possible through the generous support of an Arthur James Boucot Research Grant from the Paleontological Society. ARB thanks the ISGS Coal Section staff, especially Scott Elrick and his co-author W. John Nelson, for their enthusiasm and continued encouragement. Access to plant-fossil collections in the ISGS Samples Library was facilitated by Bob Mumm, Rodney D. Norby, and Kristina Bruhn, who are gratefully acknowledged. Access to the photographic facilities of the Illinois Natural History Survey by Sam Heads and Jared Thomas also is appreciated. Hans-Dieter Sues is acknowledged for his assistance with translation, as are Claudine Delcambre Brousmiche, Christopher J. Cleal, and Josef Pšenička for their discussions about identifications. Alex Stuedemann, maintenance director of TPC Deere Run Golf Course, is thanked for facilitating access to collecting sites during a return visit by WJN. Finally, B. "Xiao J., Xiao X., Zhang M., Shang Z., Chen Y.",Late Pleistocene montane vegetation and climate history from the Dajiuhu Basin in the western Hubei Province of Central China,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,22,32,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.08.001,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84939795436&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.08.001&partnerID=40&md5=6c930195a34c3099863e1987170bf011,"Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Environmental Change and Ecological Construction, College of Geography Science, Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing, China; State Key Laboratory of Lake Science and Environment, Nanjing Institute of Geography and Limnology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing, China; Jiangsu Center for Collaborative Innovation in Geographical Information Resource Dev. and Appl., Nanjing, China","Xiao, J., Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Environmental Change and Ecological Construction, College of Geography Science, Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing, China, State Key Laboratory of Lake Science and Environment, Nanjing Institute of Geography and Limnology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing, China, Jiangsu Center for Collaborative Innovation in Geographical Information Resource Dev. and Appl., Nanjing, China; Xiao, X., State Key Laboratory of Lake Science and Environment, Nanjing Institute of Geography and Limnology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing, China; Zhang, M., Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Environmental Change and Ecological Construction, College of Geography Science, Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing, China; Shang, Z., Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Environmental Change and Ecological Construction, College of Geography Science, Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing, China; Chen, Y., Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Environmental Change and Ecological Construction, College of Geography Science, Nanjing Normal University, Nanjing, China","A continuous 775-cm-long sediment core (Core B) was collected from the Dajiuhu Basin in the western Shennongjia Forest Region of Central China. The core between 775 and 144. cm in depth spanning the period from 83.4 to 9.6. ka (calibrated age, throughout this study) was studied for pollen analysis. The high-resolution pollen record revealed the histories of the vegetation succession and climate changes from 83.4 to 9.6. ka in the mountainous regions at an altitude of approximately 1,700. m. a.s.l. in Central China. The results show that five evident climate changes disclosed by the pollen record in Core B correspond to MIS (Marine Isotope Stage) 5a, MIS 4, MIS 3, the LGM (Last Glacial Maximum) of MIS 2, and the period from the deglacial of MIS 2 to the early Holocene, respectively. The temperature changes in the Dajiuhu Basin are consistent with the solar insolation in the Northern Hemisphere, the climate records in the Greenland and Guliya ice cores, the stalagmite, and the loess. However, the precipitation changes during the late Quaternary in the study area were roughly reversed with the temperature changes in the Northern Hemisphere. Therefore, the climatic patterns from 83.4 to 9.6. ka in the Dajiuhu Basin are cold and humid conditions and warm and dry conditions, which may be caused by the middle latitude position, the humid monsoon climate, and the steep mountainous geomorphology of the study area. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Climate change; Dajiuhu Basin; Late Pleistocene; Montane vegetation; Pollen,climate variation; geomorphology; Holocene; insolation; Last Glacial Maximum; mountain region; Northern Hemisphere; Pleistocene; pollen; sediment core; temperature effect; vegetation structure; Arctic; China; Dajiuhu Basin; Greenland; Greenland Ice Sheet; Guliya Ice Cap; Hubei; Shennongjia Nature Reserve; Xizang,,,,,"University of Chicago; 41373011, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 41072127, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 41272188, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 40972112, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China","This research was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China ( 41072127 , 41272188 , 40972112 , and 41373011 ), a Project Funded by the Priority Academic Program Development of Jiangsu Higher Education Institutions, and Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Environmental Change and Ecological Construction. "Zhang J.W., Huang J., D'Rozario A., Adams J.M., Zhou Z.-K.","Calocedrus shengxianensis, a late Miocene relative of C. macrolepis (Cupressaceae) from South China: Implications for paleoclimate and evolution of the genus",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,1,15,,4,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.004,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84939506468&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.004&partnerID=40&md5=d92ea4d1904edd738061612b97512da6,"Key Laboratory of Tropical Forest Ecology, Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden (XTBG), Chinese Academy of Sciences, Mengla, Yunnan, China; Laboratory of Environmental Chang in Arid Lands, Xinjiang Institute of Ecology and Geography, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 818 South Beijing Road,Urumqi, Xinjiang, China; Department of Botany, Narasinha Dutt College, 129,Bellilious Road, Howrah, India; The College of Natural Sciences, Seoul National University, 1 Gwanak-ro,Gwanak-gu, Seoul, South Korea","Zhang, J.W., Key Laboratory of Tropical Forest Ecology, Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden (XTBG), Chinese Academy of Sciences, Mengla, Yunnan, China, Laboratory of Environmental Chang in Arid Lands, Xinjiang Institute of Ecology and Geography, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 818 South Beijing Road,Urumqi, Xinjiang, China; Huang, J., Key Laboratory of Tropical Forest Ecology, Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden (XTBG), Chinese Academy of Sciences, Mengla, Yunnan, China; D'Rozario, A., Department of Botany, Narasinha Dutt College, 129,Bellilious Road, Howrah, India; Adams, J.M., The College of Natural Sciences, Seoul National University, 1 Gwanak-ro,Gwanak-gu, Seoul, South Korea; Zhou, Z.-K., Key Laboratory of Tropical Forest Ecology, Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden (XTBG), Chinese Academy of Sciences, Mengla, Yunnan, China","The diversification of the relict genus Calocedrus Kurz (Cupressaceae) in the Neogene of eastern Asia has remained unknown due to lack of fossil evidence. A late Miocene species, Calocedrus shengxianensis (He, Sun et Liu) Zhang et Zhou comb. nov., is described on the basis of new fossil material from the Wenshan flora in SE Yunnan, SW China. The species was originally described as Fokienia shengxianensis He, Sun et Liu from the upper Miocene Shengxian flora in E Zhejiang, SE China. The new fossil material includes well-preserved compression of leafy shoots and associated impression of seed cones. Based on the comparisons, this fossil species bears most similarities to the modern Calocedrus macrolepis Kurz, which is presently endemic to eastern Asia, in N India, Laos, NE Myanmar, NE Thailand, Vietnam and S China, but does not occur in SE Yunnan and E Zhejiang. The difference between them lies primarily in the morphology of apex of lateral as well as facial leaves. With the global cooling and uplift of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau since the late Miocene, the climate in eastern Asia has changed profoundly. This has led to the disappearance of C. shengxianensis from SE Yunnan and E Zhejiang, and the leaf morphological shifts in C. macrolepis: the acute or acuminate leaf apices in the modern C. macrolepis, which are in contrast to the blunt or obtuse ones in the late Miocene C. shengxianensis, have evolved probably to adapt to the humid climate since the late Miocene. © 2015.",Calocedrus; China; Global cooling; Morphology; Taxonomy; Upper Miocene,adaptation; climate effect; coniferous tree; fossil record; global climate; humid environment; Miocene; morphology; new genus; paleoclimate; paleoecology; taxonomy; China; Wenshan; Yunnan; Calocedrus; Calocedrus macrolepis; Cupressaceae; Fokienia,,,,,"CAS, Chinese Academy of Sciences; RAS, Russian Academy of Sciences; 41372035, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China","This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China ( 41372035 ). Polevova S.V.,Ultrastructure and development of sporoderm in Aristolochia clematitis (Aristolochiaceae),2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,104,115,,1,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.08.004,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84941145504&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.08.004&partnerID=40&md5=51de74b64a007156e0092d3febf909d5,"Biological Faculty of Lomonosov Moscow State University, Leninskie gory 1, Moscow, Russian Federation","Polevova, S.V., Biological Faculty of Lomonosov Moscow State University, Leninskie gory 1, Moscow, Russian Federation","The purpose of this study was to investigate the sporoderm development of inaperturate pollen grains in Aristolochia clematitis (Aristolochiaceae). During successive microsporogenesis several types of tetrads are formed; no tetrahedral tetrads were observed. In the tetrad period, the primexine is observed around the perimeter of microspores. In the free microspore period, a thick lamellar endexine develops around the perimeter of the microspore; the thick tubular intine appears later in this period. At the maturation of pollen grains, the intine is stratified into two layers: an outer tubular ectintine and an inner homogeneous endintine. Finally, the intine forms an aperture thickening. The thickened intine deforms and displaces the endexine and tears the ectexine apart. This shows that pollen grains of A. clematitis are aperturate. The apertures are colpi. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Aperture; Aristolochia clematitis; Lamellate endexine; Sporoderm development; Sporoderm ultrastructure; Tubulate intine,developmental biology; dicotyledon; pollen; spore; sporulation; ultrastructure; Aristolochia clematitis; Aristolochiaceae,,,,,"MSU, Mahasarakham University; 14-04-00044a, RFBR, Russian Foundation for Basic Research; 13-04-00624a, RFBR, Russian Foundation for Basic Research; TEM, Työ- ja Elinkeinoministeriö","Sincere thanks go to G.V. Degtjareva (Botanical Garden, MSU) for the plant material, to N.P. Matveeva (Biology faculty, MSU) for assistance with fluorescent microscopy and to A.G. Bogdanov (Electron Microscopy Laboratory, MSU) for technical assistance on SEM and TEM. The author is also very grateful to anonymous reviewers for linguistic corrections and valuable suggestions, which helped to improve the manuscript. "Pérez-Gutiérrez M.A., Suárez-Santiago V.N., Fernández M.C., Salinas Bonillo M.J., Romero-García A.T.",Pollen morphology and post-tetrad wall development in the subfamily Fumarioideae (Papaveraceae),2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,33,47,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.009,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84940040241&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.009&partnerID=40&md5=665488d52b1fbf9c6bcad7a950c6cc6b,"Department of Botany, Faculty of Sciences, University of Granada, c/ Severo Ochoa s/n, Granada, Spain; Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Sciences, University of Granada, c/ Severo Ochoa s/n, Granada, Spain; Department of Biology and Geology, University of Almería, c/ Carretera de Sacramento s/n, Almería, Spain","Pérez-Gutiérrez, M.A., Department of Botany, Faculty of Sciences, University of Granada, c/ Severo Ochoa s/n, Granada, Spain; Suárez-Santiago, V.N., Department of Botany, Faculty of Sciences, University of Granada, c/ Severo Ochoa s/n, Granada, Spain; Fernández, M.C., Department of Cell Biology, Faculty of Sciences, University of Granada, c/ Severo Ochoa s/n, Granada, Spain; Salinas Bonillo, M.J., Department of Biology and Geology, University of Almería, c/ Carretera de Sacramento s/n, Almería, Spain; Romero-García, A.T., Department of Botany, Faculty of Sciences, University of Granada, c/ Severo Ochoa s/n, Granada, Spain","The subfamily Fumarioideae is the most diversified group of the Papaveraceae family, a eurypalinous group whose pollen information has classically been used for studying systematic issues. In this paper we present a study of pollen morphology and development of the pollen wall in most of the Fumarioideae genera excluding Hypecoum. We describe a high variability in pollen grain ornamentation and in aperture shape and number among genera of the subfamily. Remarkable features of the pollen-wall layer development in Fumarioideae are a lamellated foot layer at the young microspore stage and a granular infratectum. In the apertures, the aperture membrane formed by ectexine is absent for the subtribe Fumariinae, and the ultrastructure of the exinous oncus shows that the endexine is arranged in three different ways among the Fumarioideae representatives. From vacuolate microspore stage onward the apertures of most Fumarioideae genera are covered by a fluffy plug, while during young bicellular stage the intine under the apertures develops from the material that accumulated in the periplasmic space. We have identified significant differences between the pollen features of the tribe Fumarieae and the tribe Hypecoeae, such as psilate exine and granular infratectum. The presence of atypical pollen features in Fumarioideae is discussed within the framework of current knowledge of pollen wall development, highlighting their implications for a better understanding of pollen wall evolution. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Aperture; Fumarioideae; Papaveraceae; Pollen morphology; Pollen wall; Ultrastructure,herb; micropaleontology; morphology; paleobotany; paleoecology; palynology; pollen; ultrastructure; Fumariaceae; Hypecoum; Papaveraceae,,,,,"UGR, Universidad de Granada; CGL2008-01554/BOS ., MICINN, Ministerio de Ciencia e Innovación; TEM, Työ- ja Elinkeinoministeriö","This research was funded by the Spanish Ministry of Science and Innovation , CGL2008-01554/BOS . We want to express our thanks to the curators and gardeners of the various botanical gardens and herbaria visited for the facilities given to us to collect the material used in this paper. We are grateful for the support of Concepción Hernández Castillo, María José Martínez Guerrero and Isabel Sánchez Almazo of the Scientific Instrumentation Centre of the University of Granada for preparing our samples and TEM and SEM visualization. We also thank A. L. Tate for revising our text, and two anonymous reviewers for valuable comments to the manuscript. Appendix A","Blackmore, S., Sporoderm homologies and morphogenesis in land plants, with a discussion of Echinops sphaerocephala (Compositae) (1990) Plant Syst. "Yang S., Zheng Z., Mao L., Ferguson D.K., Huang K., Chen B., Ranhotra P.S.","Selected pollen grains from tropical Hainan Island, south China: An identification key to Quaternary pollen",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,84,103,,1,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.011,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84940826608&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.011&partnerID=40&md5=6a64aa1a2e2804cb8e805867cb1cbd1c,"Key Laboratory of Coastal Wetland Biogeosciences, China Geologic Survey, Qingdao, Shandong, China; The Key Laboratory of Marine Hydrocarbon Resources and Environment Resources, The Ministry of Land and Resources, Qingdao, Shandong, China; School of Earth Science and Geological Engineering, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China; State Key Laboratory of Palaeobiology and Stratigraphy, Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing, China; Department of Palaeontology, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria; Birbal Sahni Institute of Palaeobotany, 53 University Road, Lucknow, India","Yang, S., Key Laboratory of Coastal Wetland Biogeosciences, China Geologic Survey, Qingdao, Shandong, China, The Key Laboratory of Marine Hydrocarbon Resources and Environment Resources, The Ministry of Land and Resources, Qingdao, Shandong, China, School of Earth Science and Geological Engineering, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China; Zheng, Z., School of Earth Science and Geological Engineering, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China; Mao, L., State Key Laboratory of Palaeobiology and Stratigraphy, Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Nanjing, China; Ferguson, D.K., Department of Palaeontology, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria; Huang, K., School of Earth Science and Geological Engineering, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China; Chen, B., School of Earth Science and Geological Engineering, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China; Ranhotra, P.S., Birbal Sahni Institute of Palaeobotany, 53 University Road, Lucknow, India","Pollen keys are essential for accurate and consistent identification of Quaternary pollen, as well as pre-Quaternary fossil pollen, which in turn enables a better understanding of past biodiversity and vegetation changes. Here, we present a pollen key to 52 species of arboreal and liana plants from 26 families on tropical Hainan Island, covering representative pollen types identified in tropical Chinese Quaternary deposits. Such a pollen key along with detailed descriptions and illustrations should enable fossil pollen to be accurately identified. Nevertheless, the key is open for future improvement, so that pollen of other plants from the same study area can be accommodated when specimens become available. In their present state they should, however, aid palynological analyses of Quaternary deposits, particularly in tropical south China. Pollen identification as well as the palaeoecological and palaeobiogeographical significance of the key representative communities along the altitudinal gradient in our study area (i.e., coastal mangroves, tropical rainforest and montane rainforest) are also discussed in this paper. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Identification key; Pollen morphology; South China; Tropics,arboreal species; biodiversity; biostratigraphy; fossil record; identification key; morphology; paleobiogeography; paleoecology; palynology; Quaternary; tropical region; vine; China; Hainan; Rhizophoraceae,,,,,"201111023; 41072128, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 41230101, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 41406069, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 41372170, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 10lgzd08; 11lgjc13","This work was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grants 41230101 , 41072128 , 41372170 and 41406069 ), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (Grants 11lgjc13 and 10lgzd08 ) and Ministry of Land and Resources program, “Special foundation for scientific research on public causes” (Grant 201111023 ). Mr. Xingyi Zhao are thanked for helping edit the pollen plates. "Pujana R.R., Marenssi S.A., Santillana S.N.",Fossil woods from the Cross Valley Formation (Paleocene of Western Antarctica): Araucariaceae-dominated forests,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,222,,,56,66,,5,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.010,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84940417344&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.010&partnerID=40&md5=fd9c552078fe1074b7cf2bc5d5b03be0,"Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales, Buenos Aires, Argentina; IGEBA, UBA-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Instituto Antártico Argentino, Buenos Aires, Argentina","Pujana, R.R., Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Marenssi, S.A., IGEBA, UBA-CONICET, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santillana, S.N., Instituto Antártico Argentino, Buenos Aires, Argentina","Fossil woods from Paleocene sediments of the Cross Valley Formation (Seymour Island, Antarctic Peninsula) are anatomically studied in detail. We collected 64 samples represented almost exclusively by conifers (95%). Only three samples of not determinable angiosperm fossil wood were found. Preservation of the samples is often poor and 52% of the samples were assigned to a fossil-species. The assemblage is dominated by Agathoxylon (Araucariaceae), particularly Agathoxylon antarcticus. Araucariaceae species are joined by Protophyllocladoxylon, Phyllocladoxylon and Cupressinoxylon. Forests dominated by Araucariaceae are unusual during the Cenozoic. The high dominance of Araucariaceae woods may be a reflection of soil conditions, weather and terrain elevation. Our study supports previous hypothesis that identified differences between the paleofloras in each side of the Antarctic Peninsula during the Paleocene. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Araucariaceae; Paleobotany; Paleocene; West Antarctica; Wood anatomy,anatomy; Cenozoic; coniferous tree; flora; fossil; paleobotany; Paleocene; terrain; wood; Antarctic Peninsula; Antarctica; West Antarctica; Agathoxylon; Araucariaceae; Coniferophyta; Magnoliophyta,,,,,"PICT 2010-0649, ANPCyT, Agencia Nacional de Promoción Científica y Tecnológica; 2012-0911, ANPCyT, Agencia Nacional de Promoción Científica y Tecnológica; CONICET, Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas","The authors thank the anonymous reviewers for their corrections and suggestions that helped to improve the manuscript. This study was financed by the ANPCyT ( PICT 2010-0649 and 2012-0911 ), Instituto Antártico Argentino , British Antarctic Survey (Antarctic Science Bursary) and CONICET . "Nosova N., Kiritchkova A.",New data on the Mesozoic conifer genus Sciadopityoides Sveshnikova (Miroviaceae),2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,1,21,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.04.011,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84930201028&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.04.011&partnerID=40&md5=2e5f5897db4a646863e247ebd287147e,"Komarov Botanical Institute RAS, Ul. Prof. Popova 2, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; All Russia Petroleum Research Exploration Institute, Liteynyi pr. 39, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation","Nosova, N., Komarov Botanical Institute RAS, Ul. Prof. Popova 2, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Kiritchkova, A., All Russia Petroleum Research Exploration Institute, Liteynyi pr. 39, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation","The paper documents in detail the morphological and epidermal characters of the leaves of the Mesozoic conifer genus Sciadopityoides Sveshnikova based on the investigation of specimens from the north of East Siberia, the Urals, Ukraine and Greenland. For the first time, the leaf epidermal structures in this genus were studied with the scanning electron and the laser confocal microscopes. The species originally described as Sciadopitys arctica Abramova and Sciadopitys swetlanae Kiritchkova are shown to be identical with, respectively, Sciadopityoides crameri (Heer) Sveshnikova and Sciadopityoides brevifolia (Abramova) Hvalj. Emended descriptions are provided for Sciadopityoides ukrainensis (Doludenko) Sveshnikova and S. brevifolia; a diagnosis, missing in the original publication, is given and a lectotype is selected for S. brevifolia and an emended diagnosis is suggested for S. ukrainensis. © 2015 Elsevier B.V..",Conifer; Cretaceous; Jurassic; Miroviaceae; Sciadopityoides,coniferous tree; Cretaceous; data set; Jurassic; Mesozoic; morphology; paleoecology; paleoenvironment; Arctic; Eurasia; Greenland; Ukraine; Coniferophyta; Miroviaceae; Sciadopitys,,,,,,,"Abramova, L.N., Novyie melovyie khvoynyie severa Sredney Sibiri (1984) Leningrad, 27, pp. 210-218. , (New Cretaceous conifers of the north of Middle Siberia, in Russian), Yezhegodnik vsesoyuznogo paleontol. obschestva; Bose, M.N., Sciadopitytes variabilis n. sp. from the Arctic of Canada (1955) Nor. "Riley K.C., Woodard J.P., Hwang G.M., Punyasena S.W.",Progress towards establishing collection standards for semi-automated pollen classification in forensic geo-historical location applications,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,117,127,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.06.005,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84934756539&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.06.005&partnerID=40&md5=50dc6c5aa6c35763b58ee82362bfffc7,"The MITRE Corporation, 7515 Colshire Drive, Mclean, VA, United States; System Planning Corporation, 3601 Wilson Blvd, Arlington, VA, United States; University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, 505S. Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL, United States","Riley, K.C., The MITRE Corporation, 7515 Colshire Drive, Mclean, VA, United States; Woodard, J.P., The MITRE Corporation, 7515 Colshire Drive, Mclean, VA, United States; Hwang, G.M., The MITRE Corporation, 7515 Colshire Drive, Mclean, VA, United States, System Planning Corporation, 3601 Wilson Blvd, Arlington, VA, United States; Punyasena, S.W., University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, 505S. Goodwin Avenue, Urbana, IL, United States","The digitization of pollen grain images would permit the creation of a semi-automated system that could aid the expert palynologists in pollen classification. It would reduce cost and time-to-answer as well as improve analyst productivity. These issues are particularly critical in forensic applications. There are numerous factors that should be considered when establishing a digital database intended for semi-automated pollen classification. This paper explores a number of these issues through computer vision and machine learning assessments. The main topics evaluated are morphologically similar species-level classification, optimal training data size, how best to utilize three-dimensional data, accuracy changes due to the availability of metadata, i.e., fluctuations in analysts' confidence in taxa labeling, and using fossil data to classify modern data. This is the first known application of training on fossil data to classify modern taxa. Performances of 95.4% and 93.8% correct classification were achieved on two distinct sets of morphologically similar species-level data, surpassing previous records. We determined that a minimum of 5-10 training images per class was required to yield reasonable performance. Additionally, we established that all depth dimension slices associated with each grain were required to yield the best performance possible. Lastly, the error rate doubles due to decreasing analyst confidence and almost triples when using data from grains of varying ages, further solidifying the importance of comprehensive metadata. © 2015 Elsevier B.V..",3D classification; Automated palynology; Computer vision; Forensics; Pattern recognition; Pollen classification,automation; classification; computer vision; cost-benefit analysis; database; digitization; expert system; forensic science; fossil record; historical geography; machine learning; morphology; palynology; pattern recognition; pollen; standard (regulation); three-dimensional modeling,,,,,,,"Ahonen, T., Matas, J.C.H., Pietikainen, M., Rotation invariant image description with local binary pattern histogram fourier features (2009) Lect. "Philippe M., Pacyna G., Wawrzyniak Z., Barbacka M., Boka K., Filipiak P., Marynowski L., Thévenard F., Uhl D.",News from an old wood - Agathoxylon keuperianum (Unger) nov. comb. in the Keuper of Poland and France,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,83,91,,6,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.06.006,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84936806689&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.06.006&partnerID=40&md5=6d437425ed9a59e6d91cf2620cea194c,"Université Lyon 1 and CNRS UMR 5276, 7 rue Dubois, Villeurbanne, France; Jagiellonian University, Institute of Botany, Department of Palaeobotany and Palaeoherbarium, ul. Lubicz 46, Kraków, Poland; Faculty of Earth Science, University of Silesia, Bedzińska 60 St, Sosnowiec, Poland; Hungarian Natural History Museum, Department of Botany, 1476 Budapest, pf. 222, Hungary; W. Szafer Institute of Botany, Polish Academy of Sciences, Lubicz 46, Kraków, Poland; Department of Plant Anatomy, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary; Senckenberg Forschungsinstitut und Naturmuseum Frankfurt, Senckenberganlage 25, Frankfurt am Main, Germany; Senckenberg Center for Human Evolution and Palaeoenvironment, Institut für Geowissenschaften, Universität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany","Philippe, M., Université Lyon 1 and CNRS UMR 5276, 7 rue Dubois, Villeurbanne, France; Pacyna, G., Jagiellonian University, Institute of Botany, Department of Palaeobotany and Palaeoherbarium, ul. Lubicz 46, Kraków, Poland; Wawrzyniak, Z., Faculty of Earth Science, University of Silesia, Bedzińska 60 St, Sosnowiec, Poland; Barbacka, M., Hungarian Natural History Museum, Department of Botany, 1476 Budapest, pf. 222, Hungary, W. Szafer Institute of Botany, Polish Academy of Sciences, Lubicz 46, Kraków, Poland; Boka, K., Department of Plant Anatomy, Eötvös Loránd University, Budapest, Hungary; Filipiak, P., Faculty of Earth Science, University of Silesia, Bedzińska 60 St, Sosnowiec, Poland; Marynowski, L., Faculty of Earth Science, University of Silesia, Bedzińska 60 St, Sosnowiec, Poland; Thévenard, F., Université Lyon 1 and CNRS UMR 5276, 7 rue Dubois, Villeurbanne, France; Uhl, D., Senckenberg Forschungsinstitut und Naturmuseum Frankfurt, Senckenberganlage 25, Frankfurt am Main, Germany, Senckenberg Center for Human Evolution and Palaeoenvironment, Institut für Geowissenschaften, Universität Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany","New fossil woods from the Keuper of Poland and France are assigned to Agathoxylon keuperianum (Unger) nov. comb. A complete nomenclatural treatment of this taxon is given, with up-dated nomenclatural synonymy and some taxonomical notes. It is shown that Zimmermann's choice of a lectotype (1953) for this species is superseded by material in the Unger collection at the Paris Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle (France). Taxomical reappraisal of Unger collection also evidenced that Simplioxylon hungaricum Andreanzsky correct name is Simplicioxylon wurtembergicum (Unger) nov. comb. and that Peuce brauneana Unger can be excluded from Agathoxylon keuperianum synonymy. Literature data for Agathoxylon keuperianum are reviewed and some are invalidated. Our new data are the first safe reports for this species outside from Germany. The systematic position of Agathoxylon keuperianum is discussed, as well as its stratigraphical and geographical range. In the present state of knowledge it seems to be restricted to the area where German Keuper is deposited. Anatomical features suggest that Agathoxylon keuperianum thrived under warm and wet conditions, whereas German Keuper sediments globally suggest hot and dry climate. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Agathoxylon; Europe; Nomenclature; Palaeoecology; Taxonomy; Triassic,fossil record; Keuper; literature review; lithostratigraphy; new record; nomenclature; paleoecology; taxonomy; type section; wood; Europe; Agathoxylon,,,,,"PAN, Polska Akademia Nauk; DEC-2012/05/B/NZ8/00990, NCN, Narodowe Centrum Nauki","Gilles Cuny kindly shared his knowledge of north-eastern France Upper Triassic. Fabrice Malartre's help while searching the Nancy palaeontological collection is much appreciated, as well as his information about the Carnian Pluvial Event. Dario de Franceschi help in Muséum National d'Histoire Naturelle was much appreciated, just as that of Daniel Contini in Université de Besançon palaeontological collections. "Griener K.W., Warny S.","Nothofagus pollen grain size as a proxy for long-term climate change: An applied study on Eocene, Oligocene, and Miocene sediments from Antarctica",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,138,143,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.06.003,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84936889185&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.06.003&partnerID=40&md5=afffffe1808aa463c8fef46108c5e9b0,"Louisiana State University, Department of Geology and Geophysics, Baton Rouge, LA, United States","Griener, K.W., Louisiana State University, Department of Geology and Geophysics, Baton Rouge, LA, United States; Warny, S., Louisiana State University, Department of Geology and Geophysics, Baton Rouge, LA, United States","Understanding the nature of moisture availability in the Eocene, Oligocene, and Miocene of Antarctica is imperative for climate reconstructions and for understanding the potential influence of future climate change on modern landscapes. Previous studies have used traditional palynological techniques, fossil leaf margins, hydrogen isotope leaf waxes, and palynomorph δ13C values to indicate changes in moisture on the southernmost continent. Here, we explore the relationship between pollen width (equatorial diameter) and climate as a potential indicator of changes in moisture availability in Antarctica, a technique that had not been widely applied previously. To date, studies of pollen grain size response to environmental stress and the applicability of using fossil pollen grain size as a climate change proxy are limited. In this paper, we explore the relationship between pollen grain size and environmental stress (desiccation intensity) and whether such a relationship can be applied to fossil pollen from Antarctica. We measured the widths of 157 modern specimens of Nothofagus spp. (the genus of Southern beech) pollen from throughout the Southern Hemisphere and compared them with mean annual precipitation records to assess the relationship between pollen grain size and moisture availability. The widths of 458 Antarctic Nothofagidites lachlaniae-complex pollen grains (from Eocene, Oligocene, and Miocene cores) were then measured and compared to other paleoenvironmental proxies to evaluate whether or not a significant trend in size variability can be associated with a change in moisture availability through geological time. Modern data show a significant relationship between decreased moisture availability and increased pollen grain size and are consistent with a previous study, providing confidence for using changes in pollen grain size as an indicator of moisture. Fossil data show a 23% increase in average pollen grain size from the late Eocene through the early to mid Miocene, indicating a decrease in moisture availability in Antarctica during this time. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Antarctica; Cenozoic; Climate; Nothofagus; Pollen; Size,climate variation; dicotyledon; environmental stress; Eocene; fossil record; grain size; long-term change; Miocene; moisture flux; Oligocene; paleoecology; paleoenvironment; palynology; palynomorph; proxy climate record; Southern Hemisphere; Antarctica; Fagus; Nothofagidites; Nothofagus,,,,,"UF, University of Florida; Core; 101072; SW; 1048343; GIS, Genome Institute of Singapore","We thank the Herbarium at the Museum of New Zealand and the Harvard University Herbarium for providing modern Nothofagus specimens and J. Ian Raine, Lowell Urbatsch, and Jennifer Kluse for assistance in obtaining herbaria material. Thanks to the Antarctic Research Facility at the University of Florida for core sampling and SHALDRIL and ANDRILL research teams for core collection. Funding for this project was provided through the NSF CAREER program (Grant # 1048343 to SW) and through the Louisiana State University Marathon GeoDE Fellowship (Grant # 101072 to KWG). Additional thanks are extended to Daniel Buechmann, who helped access precipitation data in the BIOCLIM package using GIS software. "Davies H., Fyfe R., Charman D.",Does peatland drainage damage the palaeoecological record?,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,92,105,,3,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.05.009,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84934272258&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.05.009&partnerID=40&md5=e3bb19367b0eb5257cd960313c6c27d7,"Environment Department, University of York, Heslington, York, United Kingdom; School of Geography, Earth and Environmental Sciences, Plymouth University, Plymouth, United Kingdom; Department of Geography, College of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Exeter, Amory Building, Rennes Drive, Exeter, United Kingdom","Davies, H., Environment Department, University of York, Heslington, York, United Kingdom; Fyfe, R., School of Geography, Earth and Environmental Sciences, Plymouth University, Plymouth, United Kingdom; Charman, D., Department of Geography, College of Life and Environmental Sciences, University of Exeter, Amory Building, Rennes Drive, Exeter, United Kingdom","Upland peatlands in the UK are important sources of palaeoenvironmental information, providing context to human land use in upland areas. Land management practices, particularly over the last 150. years have resulted in damage to the integrity of this palaeoenvironmental record. This study focuses on the effects of drainage on the condition of pollen remains within upland peat deposits using a case study from Exmoor, southwest England. Water-table monitoring and coring across three mires enabled the effects of water-table draw-down on the condition of pollen remains within the peat matrix to be assessed. Our results show that peatland drainage, which has taken place over the last 60-150. years, caused significant localised water-table draw-down. A detailed pollen condition survey across seven coring sites demonstrates that pollen within the peat is damaged as a consequence. However, pollen is rarely so damaged that counted pollen assemblages are unreliable. Correspondence between pollen condition and past climate shifts and periods of enhanced human activity, suggests that recent damage to pollen caused by peatland drainage is superimposed on damage caused by other factors throughout the period of peat accumulation. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Numerical methods; Paleoenvironmental resource management; Peatland drainage; Pollen condition; Upland peat; Water-table monitoring,damage; drainage; human activity; land management; land use change; management practice; numerical method; paleoecology; paleoenvironment; palynology; peatland; resource management; upland region; water table; England; Exmoor; United Kingdom,,,,,,"This study was funded by Great Western Research and the Exmoor National Park Sustainable Development Fund . "Niemeyer B., Klemm J., Pestryakova L.A., Herzschuh U.",Relative pollen productivity estimates for common taxa of the northern Siberian Arctic,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,71,82,,9,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.06.008,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84936762178&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.06.008&partnerID=40&md5=4a7cb8657222c0f81bbaf203b3fe76cf,"Periglacial Research Section, Alfred Wegener Institute Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research, Telegrafenberg A43, Potsdam, Germany; Institute for Earth and Environmental Science, University of Potsdam, Karl-Liebknecht-Str. 24-25, Potsdam-Golm, Germany; Department for Geography and Biology, North-eastern Federal University of Yakutsk, Belinskogo 58, Yakutsk, Russian Federation","Niemeyer, B., Periglacial Research Section, Alfred Wegener Institute Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research, Telegrafenberg A43, Potsdam, Germany; Klemm, J., Periglacial Research Section, Alfred Wegener Institute Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research, Telegrafenberg A43, Potsdam, Germany; Pestryakova, L.A., Department for Geography and Biology, North-eastern Federal University of Yakutsk, Belinskogo 58, Yakutsk, Russian Federation; Herzschuh, U., Periglacial Research Section, Alfred Wegener Institute Helmholtz Centre for Polar and Marine Research, Telegrafenberg A43, Potsdam, Germany, Institute for Earth and Environmental Science, University of Potsdam, Karl-Liebknecht-Str. 24-25, Potsdam-Golm, Germany","Pollen productivity estimates (PPE) are used to quantitatively reconstruct variations in vegetation within a specific distance of the sampled pollen archive. Here, for the first time, PPEs from Siberia are presented. The study area (Khatanga region, Krasnoyarsk territory, Russia) is located in the Siberian Sub-arctic where Larix is the sole forest-line forming tree taxon. Pollen spectra from two different sedimentary environments, namely terrestrial mosses (n=16) and lakes (n=15, median radius~100m) and their surrounding vegetation were investigated to extract PPEs. Our results indicate some differences in pollen spectra between moss and lake pollen. Larix and Cyperaceae for example obtained higher representation in the lacustrine than in terrestrial moss samples. This highlights that in calibration studies, modern and fossil datasets should use archives of similar sedimentary origin. Results of an Extended R-Value model were applied to assess the relevant source area of pollen (RSAP) and to calculate the PPEs for both datasets. As expected, the RSAP of the moss samples was very small (about 10m) compared to the lacustrine samples (about 25km). Calculation of PPEs for the six most common taxa yielded generally similar results for both datasets. Relative to Poaceae (reference taxon, PPE=1) Betula nana-type (PPE<inf>moss</inf>: 1.8, PPE<inf>lake</inf>: 1.8) and Alnus fruticosa-type (PPE<inf>moss</inf>:6.4, PPE<inf>lake</inf>:2.9) were overrepresented while Cyperaceae (PPE<inf>moss</inf>:0.5, PPE<inf>lake</inf>:0.1), Ericaceae (PPE<inf>moss</inf>: 0.3, PPE<inf>lake</inf><0.01), Salix (PPE<inf>moss</inf>:0.03, PPE<inf>lake</inf><00.1) and Larix (PPE<inf>moss</inf>: <0.01, PPE<inf>lake</inf>:0.2) were under-represented in the pollen spectra compared to the vegetation in the RSAP. The estimation for the dominant tree in the region, Larix gmelinii, is the first published result for this species, but needs to be considered very preliminary. The inferred sequence from over- to under-representation is mostly consistent with results from Europe; however, the absolute values show some differences. Gathering vegetation data was limited by the remoteness of our study area and a lack of high-resolute satellite imagery and vegetation maps. Our estimate may serve as a first reference to strengthen future vegetation reconstructions in this climate-sensitive region. © 2014 Elsevier B.V.",Extended R-Value model; Khatanga river; Lacustrine surface samples; Moss samples; Pollen source area,climate variation; coniferous tree; data set; lacustrine deposit; mapping method; moss; palynology; pollen; reconstruction; satellite imagery; sedge; Khatanga Basin; Krasnoyarsk [Russian Federation]; Krasnoyarsk [Russian Federation]; Russian Federation; Siberia; Alnus fruticosa; Betula nana; Bryophyta; Cyperaceae; Ericaceae; Larix; Larix gmelinii; Poaceae; Salix,,,,,"RFBR, Russian Foundation for Basic Research; 13-05-00327, RFBR, Russian Foundation for Basic Research; BMBF, Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung; 01DJ14003, BMBF, Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung; Minobrnauka, Ministry of Education and Science of the Russian Federation","We thank Xenia Schreiber, Mareike Wieczorek, Romy Zibulski, Ruslan Gorodnichev, Alexey Kolmogorov and Alexey Pestryakov for assisting us with the field work; and Thomas Böhmer for his support about the data treatment in ArcGIS. Furthermore, we are grateful to Shinya Sugita for deployment of the ERV-Model. We also thank the two anonymous referees for improving the quality of our manuscript by making valuable comments and annotations. This research was performed within the joint Russian-German Arctic Ecological Network ( Arc-EcoNet ) supported by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF grant No. 01DJ14003 ), by the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (RFBR grant No. 13-05-00327 ) and conducted in the frame of research activities defined by the Russian Ministry of Education and Science. "Saba M.D., Santos F.A.R.",Pollen morphology and exine ultrastructure of selected species of Waltheria L. (Byttnerioideae-Malvaceae),2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,204,210,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.007,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84939189074&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.007&partnerID=40&md5=c337fd16e758c25c2b950d898d42bcee,"Laboratório de Estudos Palinológicos, Departamento de Educação-Campus VII, Universidade do Estado da Bahia (UNEB), Senhor do Bonfim, Bahia, Brazil; Laboratório de Micromorfologia Vegetal, Departamento de Ciências Biológicas, Universidade Estadual de Feira de Santana (UEFS), Feira de Santana, Bahia, Brazil","Saba, M.D., Laboratório de Estudos Palinológicos, Departamento de Educação-Campus VII, Universidade do Estado da Bahia (UNEB), Senhor do Bonfim, Bahia, Brazil; Santos, F.A.R., Laboratório de Micromorfologia Vegetal, Departamento de Ciências Biológicas, Universidade Estadual de Feira de Santana (UEFS), Feira de Santana, Bahia, Brazil","The pollen morphology of five species: Waltheria albicans Turczaninow, Waltheria brachypetala Turczaninow, Waltheria cinerascens Auguste Saint-Hilaire, Waltheria martiana Bentham ex J.G. Saunders, and Waltheria viscosissima Auguste Saint-Hilaire were studied by light microscopy (LM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), focusing on apertural type and exine. Pollen grains are medium to large, isopolar, oblate spheroidal to prolate spheroidal, 3(-4)-5(-6)-zonocolporate, costate, and fastigiate. Exine ornamentation is microreticulate, homobrochate, suprareticulate (longistyled morph), and microechinate to echinate (brevistyled morph). Sexine thickness is equal to or greater than the nexine. In TEM, the sexine consists of four layers, having an inner sexine 1, and outer sexine 4. An ultrathin section of exine revealed a columellate-like intine on pollen grains of W. cinerascens. © 2015 Elsevier B.V..",Heterostyly; Malvaceae; Palynology; Pollen dimorphism; Sterculiaceae,dicotyledon; dimorphism; morphology; palynology; pollen; ultrastructure; Byttnerioideae; Malvaceae; Waltheria; Waltheria viscosissima,,,,,"CNPq, Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico; SPF, Singapore Police Force; FIOCRUZ, Fundação Oswaldo Cruz; UCONN, University of Connecticut; TEM, Työ- ja Elinkeinoministeriö; U.S. EAC, U.S. Election Assistance Commission; FIOCRUZ, Fundação Oswaldo Cruz","The authors thank the Fundação Oswaldo Cruz (FIOCRUZ), mainly Marcos André Vannier and Claudio Pereira, of the Platform for Electron Microscopy, and the Gonçalo Moniz Research Center, for their assistance in TEM analyses. "Phuphumirat W., Zetter R., Hofmann C.-C., Ferguson D.K.",Pollen degradation in mangrove sediments: A short-term experiment,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,106,116,,4,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.06.004,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84965159547&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.06.004&partnerID=40&md5=c6f87e921304733a29a882304be4757a,"Department of Paleontology, Geocenter, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria","Phuphumirat, W., Department of Paleontology, Geocenter, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria; Zetter, R., Department of Paleontology, Geocenter, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria; Hofmann, C.-C., Department of Paleontology, Geocenter, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria; Ferguson, D.K., Department of Paleontology, Geocenter, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria","In order to examine pollen deterioration inmangrove sediments, surface sediment samples were collected from 4 different mangrove communities, placed in nylon gauze bags, and then buried back into their own vegetation in October 2010. At periods of 2, 4, and 6months after burial, sediment bags were retrieved and examined. At each recovery, palynomorph percentages and concentrations were calculated as a means to investigate degradation rates of deposited palynomorphs and some physical factors affecting their preservation. It was found that although mangrove sediments are assumed to represent perfect depositional environments for the preservation of mangrove pollen due to the anoxic conditions, a high potential for loss of pollen was observed. Palynomorphs decayedmore rapidly in the Ceriops tagal - Bruguiera spp. community,whereas this process seems to proceed at a slower rate in the Rhizophora apiculata - Bruguiera spp. community, possibly controlled by differences in sediment pH, salinity, grain size, and organic matter. The good pollen preservation of Rhizophora apiculata and Sonneratia alba in their own plant communites allow them to act as useful indicators of the forest communities in which they are dominant. On the other hand, quantitative compositional reliabilities of pollen from Avicennia alba, Bruguiera spp., and Ceriops tagal, tended toweaken by their progressive deterioration and poor preservation. However, a long term-experiment is still necessary to achieve a more accurate estimation of biases from such important taphonomic factors. © Elsevier B.V. "Shumilovskikh L.S., Schlütz F., Achterberg I., Kvitkina A., Bauerochse A., Leuschner H.H.",Pollen as nutrient source in Holocene ombrotrophic bogs,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,171,178,,4,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.07.001,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937469276&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.07.001&partnerID=40&md5=655ec26c2058be9ca5a0509bc59bf4fc,"Department of Palynology and Climate Dynamics, Georg-August-University of Göttingen, Göttingen, Germany; Laboratory of Biogeochemical and Remote Techniques of Environmental Monitoring, National Research Tomsk State University, Tomsk, Russian Federation; Mediterranean Institute of Marine and Terrestrial Biodiversity and Ecology, (IMBE UMR CNRS 7263/IRD 237/Aix-Marseille University), Europôle Méditerranéen de l'Arbois, Pavillon Villemin BP 80, Aix-en-Provence Cedex 04, France; Lower Saxony Institute for Historical Coastal Research, Viktoriastrasse 26/28, Wilhelmshaven, Germany; Inst. of Physicochemical and Biological Problems in Soil Science of the Russian Academy of Sciences, ul. Institutskaya 2, Pushchino, Moscow Oblast, Russian Federation; Lower Saxony State Service for Cultural Heritage, Scharnhorststrasse 1, Hannover, Germany","Shumilovskikh, L.S., Department of Palynology and Climate Dynamics, Georg-August-University of Göttingen, Göttingen, Germany, Laboratory of Biogeochemical and Remote Techniques of Environmental Monitoring, National Research Tomsk State University, Tomsk, Russian Federation, Mediterranean Institute of Marine and Terrestrial Biodiversity and Ecology, (IMBE UMR CNRS 7263/IRD 237/Aix-Marseille University), Europôle Méditerranéen de l'Arbois, Pavillon Villemin BP 80, Aix-en-Provence Cedex 04, France; Schlütz, F., Lower Saxony Institute for Historical Coastal Research, Viktoriastrasse 26/28, Wilhelmshaven, Germany; Achterberg, I., Department of Palynology and Climate Dynamics, Georg-August-University of Göttingen, Göttingen, Germany; Kvitkina, A., Inst. of Physicochemical and Biological Problems in Soil Science of the Russian Academy of Sciences, ul. Institutskaya 2, Pushchino, Moscow Oblast, Russian Federation; Bauerochse, A., Lower Saxony State Service for Cultural Heritage, Scharnhorststrasse 1, Hannover, Germany; Leuschner, H.H., Department of Palynology and Climate Dynamics, Georg-August-University of Göttingen, Göttingen, Germany","Several laboratory experiments and field observations demonstrate that saprotrophic and ectomycorrhizal fungi effectively use pollen cytoplasm and suggest pollen produced by wind-pollinated trees as a crucial nutrient source for fungi and their plant hosts in nutrient-limited environments. However, the role of such interactions is still underestimated or neglected in ecology and paleoecology. Here, we consider pollen attacked by fungi in palynological records from Holocene raised peat bogs as a nutrient source for ecosystems in the past. The attacks occurred through the pollen germination areas by a variety of saprotrophic, ericoid mycorrhizal, ectomycorrhizal or dark septate endophyte fungi. Large amounts of attacked pollen in phases rich in Calluna vulgaris highlight the importance of Ericaceae shrubs, hosting ericoid mycorrhizal fungi and forming hotspots of decomposition in nutrient-deficit bogs. Applying estimations of pollen rain from literature, and based on own observed pollen infection rates we estimate the annual release of nitrogen, phosphate and potassium from pollen, and highlight their significance in pushing the ecosystem nutrient cycle in early spring time, when several species release their pollen. We highlight the significant role of anthropogenic changes in pollen deposition for pre-industrial bogs and hypothesize about the consequences of the pollen-based interrelation between wind-pollinated plants and their mycorrhizal fungi in paleoecology and evolution. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Anemophily; Decomposition; Fungus; Non-pollen palynomorph; Paleoecology,anemophily; anthropogenic effect; cytoplasm; decomposition; ectomycorrhiza; fungus; germination; Holocene; nutrient availability; nutrient limitation; ombrotrophic environment; paleoecology; palynology; peatland; pollen; pollen rain; saprotrophy; shrub; Calluna vulgaris; Ericaceae; Fungi,,,,,"LE 1805, DFG, California Department of Fish and Game; HA 4439, DFG, California Department of Fish and Game; Minobrnauka, Ministry of Education and Science of the Russian Federation","We thank Shinya Sugita for fruitful discussions, Bas van Geel, an anonymous reviewer and the editor for improving the manuscript and Laura Sutcliffe for polishing the English language. "Heinrichs J., Kettunen E., Lee G.E., Marzaro G., Pócs T., Ragazzi E., Renner M.A.M., Rikkinen J., Sass-Gyarmati A., Schäfer-Verwimp A., Scheben A., Solórzano Kraemer M.M., Svojtka M., Schmidt A.R.","Lejeuneaceae (Marchantiophyta) from a species-rich taphocoenosis in Miocene Mexican amber, with a review of liverworts fossilised in amber",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,221,,,59,70,,18,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.05.007,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84934975012&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.05.007&partnerID=40&md5=fc7dacd1887a0bb2780c0b17e45c9425,"Department of Biology I, University of Munich (LMU), Systematic Botany and Mykology, GeoBio-Center, Menzinger Str. 67, Munich, Germany; Department of Biosciences, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 65, Finland; Department of Pharmaceutical and Pharmacological Sciences, University of Padova, via Marzolo 5, Padova, Italy; Botany Department of Eszterházy College, Institute of Biology, Eger Pf. 43, Hungary; Department of Pharmaceutical and Pharmacological Sciences, University of Padova, Largo E.
