"Kettunen E., Grabenhorst H., Gröhn C., Dörfelt H., Sadowski E.-M., Rikkinen J., Schmidt A.R.",The enigmatic hyphomycete Torula sensu Caspary revisited,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,183,193,,3,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.03.010,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84929087007&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.03.010&partnerID=40&md5=9a3c07aadedabe06899aa49564779d89,"Department of Biosciences, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 65, Finland; Amber Study Group, C/o Geological-Palaeontological Museum of the University of Hamburg, Bundesstraße 55, Hamburg, Germany; Microbial Communication, Friedrich Schiller University Jena, Neugasse 25, Jena, Germany; Department of Geobiology, University of Göttingen, Goldschmidtstraße 3, Göttingen, Germany","Kettunen, E., Department of Biosciences, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 65, Finland; Grabenhorst, H., Amber Study Group, C/o Geological-Palaeontological Museum of the University of Hamburg, Bundesstraße 55, Hamburg, Germany; Gröhn, C., Amber Study Group, C/o Geological-Palaeontological Museum of the University of Hamburg, Bundesstraße 55, Hamburg, Germany; Dörfelt, H., Microbial Communication, Friedrich Schiller University Jena, Neugasse 25, Jena, Germany; Sadowski, E.-M., Department of Geobiology, University of Göttingen, Goldschmidtstraße 3, Göttingen, Germany; Rikkinen, J., Department of Biosciences, University of Helsinki, P.O. Box 65, Finland; Schmidt, A.R., Department of Geobiology, University of Göttingen, Goldschmidtstraße 3, Göttingen, Germany","About 130. years ago Robert Caspary described fossil fungi resembling the extant anamorphic genus Torula Persoon (Ascomycota, Pezizomycotina) from two pieces of Eocene Baltic amber. Despite being among the earliest fungi recognized from amber, these microfossils have received virtually no attention for the past 100. years. Our recent findings of similar fungal inclusions from Baltic and Bitterfeld amber have revealed that these fungi constituted an abundant, but poorly understood component of these Paleogene amber forests. Here we elucidate the morphology and growth mode of these enigmatic fungi and show that they are clearly distinguished from the moniliform hyphae of capnodialean sooty moulds (Ascomycota, Capnodiales), that they also do not correspond with the extant genus Torula, and cannot with confidence be assigned to any extant genus of dematiaceous hyphomycetes. The life cycle of the fungi involved transitions from vegetative hyphae to conidial states producing non-randomly disarticulating chains of multi-cellular phragmoconidia. We provide an emended description of these fungi and suggest a new fossil genus Casparyotorula that comprises three anamorphic species, Casparyotorula globulifera (Caspary) comb. nov., Casparyotorula heteromorpha (Caspary) comb. nov., and Casparyotorula arnoldii sp. nov. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Amber; Ascomycota; Casparyotorula; Conidiogenesis; Dematiaceous hyphomycetes; Fossil fungi,Eocene; fossil assemblage; life cycle; morphology; yeast; Ascomycota; Capnodiales; Fungi; Heteromorpha; Hyphomycetes; Pezizomycotina; Torula,,,,,,,"Berkeley, M.J., On three species of mould detected by Dr. Thomas in the amber of East Prussia (1848) Annals and Magazine of Natural History, 2, pp. 380-383. , ser. 2; Blumenstengel, H., Zur Palynologie und Stratigraphie der Bitterfelder Bernsteinvorkommen (Tertiär) (2004) Exkursionsführer und Veröffentlichungen der Deutschen Gesellschaft für Geowissenschaften, 224, p. 17; Caspary, R., Einige neue Pflanzenreste aus dem Samländischen Bernstein (1886) Schriften der physikalisch-ökonomischen Gesellschaft zu Königsberg, 27, pp. 1-8; Caspary, R., Klebs, R., Die Flora des Bernsteins und anderer fossiler Harze des ostpreußischen Tertiars (1907) Abhandlungen der Königlich Preußischen Geologischen Landesanstalt, Berlin, Neue Folge, 4, pp. 1-181; Caspary, R., Klebs, R., Atlas von dreissig Tafeln zu der Abhandlung: Die Flora des Bernsteins und anderer fossiler Harze des ostpreußischen Tertiärs (1907) Abhandlungen der Königlich Preußischen Geologischen Landesanstalt, Berlin; Crane, J.L., A nomenclator of Torula Pers.: Fr. and Torula Sensu Turpin (2001) Mycotaxon, 80, pp. 109-162; Dunlop, J., Bitterfeld amber (2010) Biodiversity of Fossils in Amber, pp. 57-68. , Siri Scientific Press, Manchester, D. "Zhang Z.-Y., Harrison S.P., Mosbrugger V., Ferguson D.K., Paudayal K.N., Trivedi A., Li C.-S.",Evaluation of the realism of climate reconstruction using the Coexistence Approach with modern pollen samples from the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,172,182,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.03.011,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84928691266&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.03.011&partnerID=40&md5=c4d397a41fd61133905882360d469fb0,"State Key Laboratory of Systematic and Evolutionary Botany, Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xiangshan, Beijing, China; University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China; Department of Biological Sciences, Macquarie University, North Ryde, NSW, Australia; Centre for Past Climate Change, School of Archaeology, Geography and Environmental Sciences, University of Reading, Whiteknights, Reading, United Kingdom; Senckenberg Research Institute and Natural History Museum, Senckenberganlage 25, Frankfurt/Main, Germany; Department of Palaeontology, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria; Central Department of Geology, Tribhuvan University, Kirtipur, Kathmandu, Nepal; Birbal Sahni Institute of Palaeobotany, University Road, Lucknow, India","Zhang, Z.-Y., State Key Laboratory of Systematic and Evolutionary Botany, Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xiangshan, Beijing, China, University of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China, Department of Biological Sciences, Macquarie University, North Ryde, NSW, Australia; Harrison, S.P., Department of Biological Sciences, Macquarie University, North Ryde, NSW, Australia, Centre for Past Climate Change, School of Archaeology, Geography and Environmental Sciences, University of Reading, Whiteknights, Reading, United Kingdom; Mosbrugger, V., Senckenberg Research Institute and Natural History Museum, Senckenberganlage 25, Frankfurt/Main, Germany; Ferguson, D.K., Department of Palaeontology, University of Vienna, Althanstrasse 14, Vienna, Austria; Paudayal, K.N., Central Department of Geology, Tribhuvan University, Kirtipur, Kathmandu, Nepal; Trivedi, A., Birbal Sahni Institute of Palaeobotany, University Road, Lucknow, India; Li, C.-S., State Key Laboratory of Systematic and Evolutionary Botany, Institute of Botany, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xiangshan, Beijing, China","We apply the Coexistence Approach (CoA) to reconstruct mean annual precipitation (MAP), mean annual temperature (MAT), mean temperature of the warmest month (MTWA) and mean temperature of the coldest month (MTCO) at 44 pollen sites on the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau. The modern climate ranges of the taxa are obtained (1) from county-level presence/absence data and (2) from data on the optimum and range of each taxon from Lu et al. (2011). The CoA based on the optimum and range data yields better predictions of observed climate parameters at the pollen sites than that based on the county-level data. The presence of arboreal pollen, most of which is derived from outside the region, distorts the reconstructions. More reliable reconstructions are obtained using only the non-arboreal component of the pollen assemblages. The root mean-squared error (RMSE) of the MAP reconstructions are smaller than the RMSE of MAT, MTWA and MTCO, suggesting that precipitation gradients are the most important control of vegetation distribution on the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau. Our results show that CoA could be used to reconstruct past climates in this region, although in areas characterized by open vegetation the most reliable estimates will be obtained by excluding possible arboreal contaminants. © 2015 .",Arboreal pollen; Climate reconstruction; Coexistence Approach; Mean annual precipitation; Pollen surface sample; Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau,,,,,,"DP1201100343, ARC, Australian Research Council; Macquarie University; SKLLQG1333, CAS, Center for African Studies; 12120113006100, USGS, U.S. Geological Survey; 90004F1005; 31300186, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 31370254, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 41072022, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China","We thank Torsten Utescher for his helpful comments on an earlier version of this paper. "Wan M., Wang J.","Nanshanopteris nervosa gen. et sp. nov., a glenopterid foliage from the Changhsingian Sunan Formation in Yumen, western China",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,39,51,,3,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.03.009,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84930225224&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.03.009&partnerID=40&md5=af6de21d866daad977f533c207b5e47f,"LPS, Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.39 Beijing Road, Nanjing, China; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, China","Wan, M., LPS, Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.39 Beijing Road, Nanjing, China, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, China; Wang, J., LPS, Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, No.39 Beijing Road, Nanjing, China","A new form of pinnate foliage, Nanshanopteris nervosa gen. et sp. nov. is described from the Changhsingian Sunan Formation in Dashankou, Gansu, western China. Pinnules are auriculate, semicircular and tongue-shaped. The apical and basal pinnules gradually decrease in size relative to those in the middle part of the frond. The venation is dichotomous and very dense. Veins are derived from the rachis at the base of lower leaf margin. Pinnules are amphistomatic. Epidermal cells of both lower and upper epidermis are polygonal, and stomata are located parallel to the subtle veins. Papillae occur on the subsidiary cells and overarch the stomatal pores; very few normal cells of the upper epidermis bear papillae. The frond morphology and cuticles suggest that the plant probably is a new member of the Peltaspermales. Based on the frond architecture, Nanshanopteris is attributed to a new form group of peltasperms named glenopteroids, which have distinctive pinnate, monopodial frond with a basally widened petiole, and alethopteroid-type pinnules. It might be an endemic species in the Cathaysian-Angaran mixed flora of western China. Judging from the characteristics of the new plant, such as the significant thickness of the cuticles, the occurrence of well-developed papillae around the deeply sunken stomata, and the association with other xeromorphic plants like conifers, and sedimentological observations suggest that the new plant probably grew along a lake margin under seasonally wet climate. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Glenopterids; Nanshan section; Nanshanopteris nervosa gen. et sp. nov; Palaeoecology; Peltaspermales; Permian,cuticle; endemic species; fern; foliage; morphology; new species; paleobotany; paleoecology; Permian; China; Dashankou; Gansu; Coniferophyta; Peltaspermales,,,,,"KZCX2-EW-120, CAS Key Project, Chinese Academy of Sciences Key Project; 41372011, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 41372010, NSFC, National Natural Science Foundation of China; 2012CB821901","We thank Mr. Xiaoyi Fan who helped to make the plates and Mr. Shengwu Mei who helped to do lots of the field work in the research areas. DiMichele and Prof. Hans Kerp whose critical and detailed comments greatly improved this paper. "Taylor T.N., Krings M.",A colony-forming microorganism with probable affinities to the Chroococcales (cyanobacteria) from the Lower Devonian Rhynie chert,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,147,156,,5,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.04.003,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84928558449&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.04.003&partnerID=40&md5=1beacfa0ae40348ad4edd976aa153485,"Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, Natural History Museum and Biodiversity Institute, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Department für Geo- und Umweltwissenschaften, Paläontologie und Geobiologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität, Bayerische Staatssammlung für Paläontologie und Geologie, Richard-Wagner-Straße 10, Munich, Germany","Taylor, T.N., Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, Natural History Museum and Biodiversity Institute, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States; Krings, M., Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, Natural History Museum and Biodiversity Institute, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS, United States, Department für Geo- und Umweltwissenschaften, Paläontologie und Geobiologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität, Bayerische Staatssammlung für Paläontologie und Geologie, Richard-Wagner-Straße 10, Munich, Germany","The Rhynie chert has provided a wealth of information on Early Devonian non-marine aquatic and terrestrial life. However, our understanding of the microbial biodiversity in this hot spring paleoecosystem remains incomplete. In this paper we describe Rhyniosarcina devonica nov. gen. et sp., a microorganism from the Rhynie chert that forms cubical, spheroidal, or irregular colonies of up to several hundred densely packed cells (<. 2.5-5.5. μm in diameter). Square groups of four cells and sarcinoid packages of eight cells represent the basic modular units in the construction of the colonies. Cell division is by binary fission in three planes in space; new colonies form by colony dissociation. Rhyniosarcina devonica is interpreted as a cyanobacterium with affinities to the Chroococcales based on morphological similarities to extant colony-forming chroococcalean cyanobacteria, especially members in the genus Cyanosarcina. This discovery expands our knowledge of the diversity of primary producers in the Rhynie chert. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Binary fission; Colony; Cyanosarcina; Myxosarcina; Pleurocapsales; Sarcinoid growth,Chroococcales; Cyanobacteria; Myxosarcina; Pleurocapsales,,,,,"Ke 584/13-2, DFG, California Department of Fish and Game; EAR-0949947, NSF, National Science Foundation; DFG, Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft","We gratefully acknowledge financial support from the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG grant Ke 584/13-2 ) and the National Science Foundation ( EAR-0949947 ). Nora Dotzler, Helmut Martin, and Stefan Sónyi (all Munich, Germany) are acknowledged for technical assistance, and Sara Taliaferro (Lawrence, KS, USA) for preparing Textfigure 1 . J. Plant Sci., 174, pp. 293-308; Kidston, R., Lang, W.H., On Old Red Sandstone plants showing structure, from the Rhynie Chert Bed, Aberdeenshire. Part I. Microbiol., 1 (4)","Krings, M.; Department für Geo- und Umweltwissenschaften, Paläontologie und Geobiologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität, Bayerische Staatssammlung für Paläontologie und Geologie, Richard-Wagner-Straße 10, Germany",,,Elsevier,,,,,346667,,RPPYA,,English,Rev. "García-Moreiras I., Sánchez J.M., Muñoz Sobrino C.",Modern pollen and non-pollen palynomorph assemblages of salt marsh and subtidal environments from the Ría de Vigo (NW Iberia),2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,157,171,,3,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.04.006,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84928675519&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.04.006&partnerID=40&md5=8e6e4dd611abc79a88b73c18250e3702,"Departamento de Bioloxía Vexetal e Ciencias do Solo, Facultad de Biología, Universidade de Vigo, Campus de Marcosende s/n., Vigo, Spain","García-Moreiras, I., Departamento de Bioloxía Vexetal e Ciencias do Solo, Facultad de Biología, Universidade de Vigo, Campus de Marcosende s/n., Vigo, Spain; Sánchez, J.M., Departamento de Bioloxía Vexetal e Ciencias do Solo, Facultad de Biología, Universidade de Vigo, Campus de Marcosende s/n., Vigo, Spain; Muñoz Sobrino, C., Departamento de Bioloxía Vexetal e Ciencias do Solo, Facultad de Biología, Universidade de Vigo, Campus de Marcosende s/n., Vigo, Spain","Pollen and non-pollen assemblages were studied in 40 surface samples obtained from different sedimentary environments of two salt marshes and the subtidal area in the Ría de Vigo (NW Iberia). The percentage and concentration distributions of pollen, dinocysts and other non-pollen palynomorphs (NPP), which include fungal and algal spores, were analyzed by numerical methods. Our purpose was to determine whether the studied environments have a characteristic pollen fingerprint. Also, we aimed to assess how the specific abiotic conditions and the local/regional vegetation of the environments studied influence the surface pollen pattern.A cluster analysis grouped the samples into six pollen classes corresponding to marsh zones with different local vegetation and abiotic conditions. A principal component analysis supported the classification and showed that most of the environments studied had characteristic pollen patterns. The best differentiated ones were those of the low marsh dominated by Halimione portulacoides (mainly characterized by the local pollen predominance) and the subtidal area (characterized by high percentages of dinocysts and regional pollen, particularly of Pinus and Erica). A gradient was also evidenced in the distribution of some palynomorphs and may respond to abiotic factors, such as altitude above the mean sea level and distance from the pollen sources.Here, we provide new data on the relationship between modern palynomorphs and coastal habitats from the Ría de Vigo that could be useful for interpreting ancient environments by comparing the modern pollen analogues with the fossil data. This study may have implications for paleoenvironmental reconstructions in coastal and shallow marine environments, particularly in those of NW Iberia. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Coastal habitat; Modern pollen assemblage; Numerical analysis; NW Iberia; Surface sample,algae; Erica; Halimione portulacoides,,,,,"Consellería de Cultura, Educación e Ordenación Universitaria, Xunta de Galicia; PRE/2013/404, Consellería de Cultura, Educación e Ordenación Universitaria, Xunta de Galicia; CGL2012-33584, MES, Ministry of Education and Science",This work was funded by the Spanish Ministry of Education and Science under research projects CGL2012-33584 (co-financed with EFRD funds) and the Xunta de Galicia 10MDS310020PR . I. García-Moreiras is supported by a PhD fellowship from the Xunta de Galicia ( PRE/2013/404 ). The authors thank the support of J. "Keizer P.S., Gajewski K., McLeman R.","Forest dynamics in relation to multi-decadal late-Holocene climatic variability, eastern Ontario, Canada",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,106,115,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.04.001,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84928243584&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.04.001&partnerID=40&md5=d1505d688d149e3c8b1ab3fbb1a8988c,"Department of Geography, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON, Canada","Keizer, P.S., Department of Geography, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON, Canada; Gajewski, K., Department of Geography, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON, Canada; McLeman, R., Department of Geography, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON, Canada","Pollen profiles from two lakes, Tawny Pond (44°48'59″N, 77°10'54″W, 276. m) and Stoll Lake (44°58'16″N, 77°17'22″W,303. m) in Addington Highlands, eastern Ontario, Canada were analyzed to determine the effects of late-Holocene climate change and European settlement on eastern Ontario's forests. Both lakes were analyzed at high temporal resolution and record vegetation dynamics over the last 1000. years. Throughout the past 1000. years, Pinus, Tsuga, Betula, Quercus, Acer and Fagus were the dominant taxa in the pollen record. From 950-1550. AD the forest was dominated by Tsuga, Fagus and Acer. Between 1550 and 1730. AD Pinus e abundant and/or had increased relative pollen production. Low pollen influx to the sediment, high values of Pinus and relatively low values of Tsuga and hardwoods between 1730 and 1870. AD suggest colder temperatures. Since 1870. AD, herbaceous plants (weeds) increased in abundance, whereas softwoods decreased and hardwoods increased, due to landscape changes associated with European settlement. A comparison of the temperature reconstruction based on the pollen assemblages and the Toronto and Ottawa climate records shows a close correspondence, suggesting pollen records can record decadal-scale climate fluctuations. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Fire history; Holocene; Lake sediments; Ontario; Pollen; Quantitative climate reconstruction,abundance; climate variation; dominance; forest dynamics; Holocene; human settlement; lake ecosystem; paleoclimate; poaching; tree; Canada; Ontario [Canada]; Acer; Betula; Fagus; Quercus; Tsuga,,,,,"SSHRC, Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada; NSERC, Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada; SSHRC, Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada; NSERC, Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada","This research was funded by grants from the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada ( SSHRC ) and the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada ( NSERC ). "Grigorjeva V., Gabarayeva N.","The development of sporoderm, tapetum and Ubisch bodies in Dianthus deltoides (Caryophyllaceae): Self-assembly in action",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,1,27,,5,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.03.005,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84930202048&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.03.005&partnerID=40&md5=64727f3242bd370bc7bee1c156d9a6c8,"Komarov Botanical Institute, Popov st., 2, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation","Grigorjeva, V., Komarov Botanical Institute, Popov st., 2, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation; Gabarayeva, N., Komarov Botanical Institute, Popov st., 2, St. Petersburg, Russian Federation","The purpose of this work was to study in detail with TEM the successive stages of pollen wall and tapetum development in Dianthus deltoides and to clarify the mechanisms underlying the developmental processes. At the young tetrad stage a thin glycocalyx layer is poorly structured, being a mixture of glycoproteins, secreted by Golgi vesicles through the process of exocytosis. At the middle tetrad stage the plasma membrane acquires a deeply invaginated profile as a result of self-assembly cellular tensegrity, and its pinnacles determine the sites of the future spines. Then, lipoid sporopollenin (SP) precursors and monomers are added into the periplasmic space. The concentrations of all substances in the periplasmic space are under genome control. As a consequence of self-assembly hydrophilic-hydrophobic interactions, ""islets"" of osmiophilic lipoid substances occur in the glycocalyx mixture, first as spherical units, then as plates, with further lateral growth and the appearance of the hexagonal reticulate pattern of the future tectum. At maturity, the reticulate pattern is not evident. At the late tetrad stage spines are initiated as outgrowths of the glycocalyx in the form of cone-like liquid-crystal ""skeletons"", the latter accumulate SP. Columellae are initiated very late in ontogeny, at the stage when the tetrads separate into monads, on the base of the glycocalyx rod-like units - the cylindrical micelles. The first endexine lamella with a central white line appears at the young free microspore stage on the base of laminate micelles. The second endexine layer is granulate and appears on the base of spherical micelles. Pollen grains are polyporate with aperturate membranes, consisting of lamellate endexine-1 and an underlying dilation - oncus - comprising granulate endexine-2. The pore membranes bear large cupola-like tectal spines. The tapetum secretes a peri-tapetal membrane with Ubisch bodies, first with clusters of globules, then exine-like spines on the top of clusters. These Ubisch bodies mimic the pattern of the exine. The entire sequence of developmental events can be explained as the development of a self-assembling system under initial genomic regulation. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Biocolloids; Micelles; Pattern formation; Self-assembly; Sporoderm and ubisch body development,cytology; dicotyledon; genomics; hydrophobicity; ontogeny; palynology; transmission electron microscopy; Caryophyllaceae; Dianthus deltoides,,,,,"14-04-00737, RFBR, Russian Foundation for Basic Research",This work was supported by RFBR grant No. 14-04-00737 to Nina Gabarayeva. "Kupryjanowicz M., Drzymulska D., Fiłoc M.",Eemian and early Weichselian Lobelia lakes in northeastern Poland,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,28,38,,1,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.03.006,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84930209169&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.03.006&partnerID=40&md5=dd0a06fc2e7a0dfed473be72e69093c4,"Department of Botany, Institute of Biology, University of Białystok, K. Ciołkowskiego 1J, Białystok, Poland","Kupryjanowicz, M., Department of Botany, Institute of Biology, University of Białystok, K. Ciołkowskiego 1J, Białystok, Poland; Drzymulska, D., Department of Botany, Institute of Biology, University of Białystok, K. Ciołkowskiego 1J, Białystok, Poland; Fiłoc, M., Department of Botany, Institute of Biology, University of Białystok, K. Ciołkowskiego 1J, Białystok, Poland","The Eemian and early Weichselian (early Vistulian in Polish stratigraphy) Lobelia lakes were investigated in an attempt to reconstruct the palaeoenvironmental conditions of northern Podlasie, northeastern Poland. Lacustrine sediments from six palaeolakes (Choroszczewo, Solniki, Dzierniakowo, Sokółka, Bohoniki and Drahle) were investigated palynologically. Furthermore, macroscopic plant remains were analysed from Bohoniki. Lobelia-lake vegetation was represented by Isoëtes, whose microspores were identified in all analysed profiles. In Bohoniki, megaspores of Isoëtes lacustris L. were also detected. Patterns of Isoëtes occurrence are evidence that during the Eemian interglacial and early Weichselian the existence of Lobelia lakes in northeastern Poland coincided with the boreal climate and the presence of boreal pine forests, which developed in the direct surroundings of the water bodies studied. These communities had the best conditions to develop in the terminal pine phase of the Eemian interglacial (E7 Pinus R PAZ), as well as during the interstadials of the early Weichselian (Brørup and Odderade). All these parts of the Late Pleistocene were relatively cold and humid. There is a similarity in the occurrence of Isoëtes between the decline parts of the Eemian interglacial, and the Holocene. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Early weichselian; Eemian interglacial; Isoëtes lacustris; Lobelia lake; Macroremain analysis; Pollen analysis,boreal forest; coniferous forest; Eemian; interglacial; lacustrine deposit; paleoenvironment; paleolimnology; palynology; reconstruction; Weichselian; Podlasie; Poland; Lobelia,,,,,"3 P04C 025 25, KBN, Komitet Badań Naukowych","The studies in Solniki and Dzierniakowo were supported by the State Committee for Scientific Research , project No. 3 P04C 025 25 .","Allen, J.R.M., Huntley, B., Weichselian palynological records from southern Europe: correlation and chronology (2000) Quat. Int., 73, pp. 111-125; Andersen, S., Vegetation and its environment in Denmark in the Early Weichselian Glacial (Last Glacial) (1961) Danm. Geol. Unders., 2 R. (75), pp. 1-175; Behre, K.-E., Pollen- und diatomeenanalytische Untersuchungen an letztinterglazialen Kieselgurlagern der Lüneburger Heide (1962) Flora, 152, pp. 325-370; Berglund, B.E., Ralska-Jasiewiczowa, M., Pollen analysis and pollen diagrams (1986) Handbook of Holocene Palaeoecology and Palaeohydrology, pp. 455-484. , John Wiley & Sons, Chichester, B.E. Berglund (Ed.); Beug, H.J., (2004) Leitfaden der Pollenbestimmung für Mitteleuropa und angrenzende Gebiete, , Friedrich Pfeil, Munich; Bińka, K., Nitychoruk, J., Cyclicity in the Eemian climate? J., 43, pp. 1351-1362","Kupryjanowicz, M.; Department of Botany, Institute of Biology, University of Białystok, K. Ciołkowskiego 1J, Poland",,,Elsevier,,,,,346667,,RPPYA,,English,Rev. Palaeobot. "Knor S., Kvaček Z., Wappler T., Prokop J.","Diversity, taphonomy and palaeoecology of plant-arthropod interactions in the lower Miocene (Burdigalian) in the Most Basin in north-western Bohemia (Czech Republic)",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,52,70,,4,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.03.004,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84927722501&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.03.004&partnerID=40&md5=eba03b73af64d94cc6414b0fd2531b3f,"Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Science, Department of Zoology, Viničná 7, Praha 2, Czech Republic; Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Science, Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Albertov 6, Praha 2, Czech Republic; Steinmann Institute for Geology, Mineralogy and Palaeontology, Division Palaeontology, University of Bonn, Nussallee 8, Bonn, Germany","Knor, S., Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Science, Department of Zoology, Viničná 7, Praha 2, Czech Republic, Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Science, Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Albertov 6, Praha 2, Czech Republic; Kvaček, Z., Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Science, Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Albertov 6, Praha 2, Czech Republic; Wappler, T., Steinmann Institute for Geology, Mineralogy and Palaeontology, Division Palaeontology, University of Bonn, Nussallee 8, Bonn, Germany; Prokop, J., Charles University in Prague, Faculty of Science, Department of Zoology, Viničná 7, Praha 2, Czech Republic","An extensive collection of nearly 4200 fossil plants remains from lower Miocene deposits at Bílina and Břešťany were examined for signs of damage caused by arthropods. Determining the frequency and diversity of plant-arthropod interactions was the main objective, followed by a comparison of the level of damage to plant taxa for which there were at least 25 specimens. There were significant differences in the frequencies of the damage caused by the different functional feeding groups in the whole assemblage and individual taxa. Comparison of the diversity of the different types of damage by rarefying their five occurrences also confirmed the differences in the levels attained. The highest diversity was recorded for deciduous trees (Alnus, Nyssa and Populus). The organisms that caused some of the highly specific types of damage, such as mining and oviposition, were taxonomically identified on the basis of their unique morphological traits. There was one remarkable non-herbivore plant-arthropod interaction represented by a solitary record of a caddisfly case built exclusively of Taxodium needles. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Damage type; Functional feeding group; Herbivory; Miocene; Most Basin; Plant-arthropod interaction,Burdigalian; feeding behavior; fossil record; herbivory; oviposition; paleoecology; plant-insect interaction; species diversity; taphonomy; taxonomy; Bohemia; Czech Republic; Alnus; Arthropoda; Nyssa; Populus; Taxodium; Trichoptera,,,,,"MSM 002162085, MŠMT, Ministerstvo Školství, Mládeže a Tělovýchovy; GAUK; 287911/2011/B-Bio/PřF; UEA, University of East Anglia; SVV-260 087/2014, UK, Univerzita Karlova v Praze; 14-23108S; WA1492/4-1","We would like to thank Zdeněk Dvořák (Bílina Mine enterprise) for his assistance and access to collection of material from the Bílina Mine enterprise, and Jiří Kvaček and Zuzana Váchová (both paleobotanists at National Museum in Prague) for access to their collections. Authors are grateful to Anthony F.G. Dixon (University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom) for improving the English. We would like also to express our thanks to Prof. Hans Kerp for his help with processing of the manuscript. S.K. acknowledges the financial support of the Grant Agency (GAUK) (No. 287911/2011/B-Bio/PřF ) during his Doctoral Study at Charles University. This work was also supported by SVV project (Integrative Animal Biology) No. SVV-260 087/2014 and another from the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports (scheme MSM 002162085 ). The research received support from grants of the German Science Foundation WA1492/4-1 (to T.W.). "Martínez L.C.A., Olivo M.S.","Tempskya in the Valanginian of South America (Mulichinco Formation, Neuquén Basin, Argentina) - Systematics, palaeoclimatology and palaeoecology",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,219,,,116,131,,4,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.04.002,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84928250042&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.04.002&partnerID=40&md5=73a829c99f4f080a0c36dc61fcec99f2,"Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales Bernardino Rivadavia - CONICET, División Paleobotánica, Avda. Ángel Gallardo 470, Buenos Aires, Argentina; Facultad de Ciencias Naturales y Museo, División Paleobotánica, Universidad Nacional de La Plata, Paseo del Bosque s/n, La Plata, Argentina; Centro de Investigaciones Geológicas, CONICET-UNLP, Calle 1No 644, La Plata, Argentina","Martínez, L.C.A., Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales Bernardino Rivadavia - CONICET, División Paleobotánica, Avda. Ángel Gallardo 470, Buenos Aires, Argentina, Facultad de Ciencias Naturales y Museo, División Paleobotánica, Universidad Nacional de La Plata, Paseo del Bosque s/n, La Plata, Argentina; Olivo, M.S., Centro de Investigaciones Geológicas, CONICET-UNLP, Calle 1No 644, La Plata, Argentina","New specimens of the tree fern Tempskya are described from the Mulichinco Formation (Valanginian), Neuquén Basin, Argentina. Tempskya is a genus for permineralized false fern trunks. This extinct genus had a wide distribution during the Early Cretaceous. However, records from the Southern Hemisphere are scarce and restricted to the late Early Cretaceous in Argentina and Australia. The Patagonian specimens here described from the Valanginian represent the oldest record of this genus. The presence of this fossil fern implies humid and warm climatic conditions during the deposition of the Mulichinco Formation in the Early Cretaceous. The new specimens show petioles, leaf remains, sporangia and spores. On the basis of these new features, a new systematic position for Tempskya is suggested. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Fossil fern; Lower Cretaceous; Mulichinco Formation; Neuquén Basin; Tempskyaceae,fern; fossil record; geographical distribution; identification key; new genus; new species; paleoclimate; paleoecology; South America; Filicophyta,,,,,"CONICET, Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas; PIP 02384; PICT-2324","We would like to thank Agustín Argüello, Rodrigo Ignacio Escobar and families from Puesto Gualmes and Puesto Victoria Nahuel for their help and cooperation during fieldwork. We would also like to thank Analía Artabe, Liliana Seoane, Ari Iglesias, Rafael Herbst, Ezequiel Vera, María Luján Luna, Gabriela Giudice, Georgina del Fueyo, Valeria Pérez Loinaze and Luis Palazzesi for their valuable suggestions and literature. This research was supported by grants: PICT-2324 (L.C.A. Martínez), and PIP 02384 ( Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Científicas y Técnicas ), (L. Spalletti), Argentina. "Dal Corso J., Roghi G., Kustatscher E., Preto N., Gianolla P., Manfrin S., Mietto P.",Ammonoid-calibrated sporomorph assemblages reflect a shift from hygrophytic to xerophytic elements in the late Anisian (Middle Triassic) of the Southern Alps (Italy),2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,15,27,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2014.02.010,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937968902&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2014.02.010&partnerID=40&md5=ab7c5d0c243e6d09e4c542b8887e797c,"Dipartimento di Geoscienze, Università degli Studi di Padova, via Gradenigo 6, Padova, Italy; Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse CNR, via Gradenigo 6, Padova, Italy; Museo di Scienze Naturali dell'Alto Adige, via Bottai 1, Bolzano, Italy; Department für Geo- und Umweltwissenschaften, Paläontologie und Geobiologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitat und Bayerische Staatssammlung fur Palaontologie und Geologie, Richard-Wagner-Straße 10, München, Germany; Dipartimento di Fisica e Scienze della Terra, via Saragat 1, Ferrara, Italy","Dal Corso, J., Dipartimento di Geoscienze, Università degli Studi di Padova, via Gradenigo 6, Padova, Italy; Roghi, G., Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse CNR, via Gradenigo 6, Padova, Italy; Kustatscher, E., Museo di Scienze Naturali dell'Alto Adige, via Bottai 1, Bolzano, Italy, Department für Geo- und Umweltwissenschaften, Paläontologie und Geobiologie, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universitat und Bayerische Staatssammlung fur Palaontologie und Geologie, Richard-Wagner-Straße 10, München, Germany; Preto, N., Dipartimento di Geoscienze, Università degli Studi di Padova, via Gradenigo 6, Padova, Italy; Gianolla, P., Dipartimento di Fisica e Scienze della Terra, via Saragat 1, Ferrara, Italy; Manfrin, S., Dipartimento di Geoscienze, Università degli Studi di Padova, via Gradenigo 6, Padova, Italy; Mietto, P., Dipartimento di Geoscienze, Università degli Studi di Padova, via Gradenigo 6, Padova, Italy","An integrated sporomorph and ammonoid biostratigraphy has been carried out in three upper Anisian (Middle Triassic) stratigraphic sections in the Southern Alps (Italy). Two main sporomorph assemblages have been defined and calibrated with ammonoids. The TrSM-A assemblage is marked by the co-occurrence of Stellapollenites thiergartii, Dyupetalum vicentinense, Cristianisporites triangulatus and Staropollenites antonescui. The TrSM-B assemblage is marked by the first occurrence of Cannanoropollis scheuringii. The boundary between the TrSM-A and TrSM-B assemblages falls in the upper part of the reitzi ammonoid subzone (Hungarites zone; Illyrian). The TrSM-A and TrSM-B assemblages have been compared and correlated with other existing sporomorph biozonations for the northwestern Tethys, the Germanic Basin and the Barents Sea.The first occurrence of the genus Ovalipollis is recorded within the assemblage TrSM-A, in the lower-middle reitzi ammonoid subzone.Quantitative palynological data coupled with previously published studies show a shift from hygrophytic to xerophytic elements in the trinodosus-lower reitzi ammonoid subzones. This change in precipitation range can be recognised in other sections in the northwestern Tethys but seems to have preceded a similar shift recorded in the Boreal realm. © 2014 Elsevier B.V.",Ammonoids; Integrated biostratigraphy; Middle Triassic; Palaeoclimate; Palynomorphs; Tethys,Ammonoidea,,,,,"COBZ090017; 17/2009; Department of Geosciences, Smith College","We thank M.L. Perissinotto for help in sample preparation at the Department of Geosciences (Padova). Thanks go to the late Prof. V. De Zanche for precious suggestions at the beginning of this study and to Prof. P.A. Hochuli that gave important inputs discussing the data. Thanks go to A.E. Götz and an anonymous reviewer whose constructive comments helped to improve the manuscript. This paper is part of the project “The Permian-Triassic ecological crisis in the Dolomites: extinction and recovery dynamics in terrestrial ecosystems” funded by the Promotion of Educational Policies, University and Research Department of the Autonomous Province of Bolzano–South Tyrol (nr. 17/2009 (COBZ090017) ). Palaeobot. Palynol.,Article,,Scopus,2-s2.0-84937968902,,,,,,,
"Cirilli S., Buratti N., Gugliotti L., Frixa A.","Palynostratigraphy and palynofacies of the Upper Triassic Streppenosa Formation (SE Sicily, Italy) and inference on the main controlling factors in the organic rich shale deposition",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,67,79,,3,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2014.10.009,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937972056&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2014.10.009&partnerID=40&md5=df9c9b3dec308bf11d1dd8f6b587f1e1,"Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, Università di Perugia, Via Pascoli, Perugia, Italy; Eni E and P, Via Emilia 1, San Donato Milanese, Milano, Italy","Cirilli, S., Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, Università di Perugia, Via Pascoli, Perugia, Italy; Buratti, N., Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, Università di Perugia, Via Pascoli, Perugia, Italy; Gugliotti, L., Eni E and P, Via Emilia 1, San Donato Milanese, Milano, Italy; Frixa, A., Eni E and P, Via Emilia 1, San Donato Milanese, Milano, Italy","This paper focuses on the Upper Triassic Streppenosa Formation, penetrated by the Pachino 4 on-shore well, (Southern Sicily, Italy) in order to find stratigraphic age constrains and to reconstruct the paleoenvironmental evolution of this basin within the Upper Triassic palaeogeographic scenario of the western Tethys. Pachino 4 is one of the wells drilled by Eni Exploration and Production in the south-eastern Hyblean plateau with the purpose to better define the time and space distribution of reservoirs and source rocks in an area characterized by considerable subsidence and strong tectonic activity, balanced by high sedimentation rate. The Streppenosa Formation depocenter consists of a thick sequence (> 2500m) of organic rich shales, turbiditic limestones and marly limestones, grouped into three members (Lower, Middle and Upper). The well diversified microflora assemblages allow the dating of the upper part of the Lower Member and the Middle Member as Norian and the Upper Member as Rhaetian. The palynofacies variations across the Streppenosa Formation show significative changes in the relative abundances of the organic debris that, associated with the lithological and sedimentological features, allowed a reconstruction of the depositional facies successions and a hypothesis for the forcing mechanisms driving the black shale deposition. We considered that the deposition of the Streppenosa Formation occurred in an epeiric basin, under oxygen-depleted bottom waters, with different depth that varied through time in response to the sedimentation rates, eustatic sea level changes, and basin subsidence. The integration of palynofacies and lithofacies data suggests a crucial role for river runoff, responsible for water stratification and for primary productivity increase in the water column. The process was triggered by warmer and wetter climate conditions as documented in many Upper Triassic successions of the western Tethys realm. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Organic matter; Palynofacies; Palynostratigraphy; Sicily; Streppenosa Formation; Triassic,climate variation; depocenter; eustacy; limestone; lithofacies; organic matter; paleoenvironment; paleogeography; palynology; reconstruction; relative abundance; runoff; sea level change; sedimentation rate; shale; spatiotemporal analysis; Tethys; Triassic; water column; Hyblean Plateau; Italy; Sicily,,,,,Core; CONLABSSOR-000934,"The authors gratefully acknowledge Eni E&P Management for permission to study the cuttings and core samples of the Pachino 4 borehole and to publish the results. We are grateful to Amalia Spina for the useful discussions and help and to Giulia Panfili for her assistance in the laboratory. We are deeply in debt with M. H. Stephenson for his accurate review that surely improved the quality of the paper. This study was supported by the funds of the Sedimentary Organic Matter Laboratory (Grant number: CONLABSSOR-000934 ), directed by S. Cirilli (Perugia University, Italy). "Combourieu-Nebout N., Bertini A., Russo-Ermolli E., Peyron O., Klotz S., Montade V., Fauquette S., Allen J., Fusco F., Goring S., Huntley B., Joannin Sé., Lebreton V., Magri D., Martinetto E., Orain R., Sadori L.",Climate changes in the central Mediterranean and Italian vegetation dynamics since the Pliocene,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,127,147,,23,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.03.001,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937970652&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.03.001&partnerID=40&md5=664779c673016bb4d59d4279e0ff96f2,"HPNP, UMR 7194 CNRS, Département de Préhistoire du Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, 1 rue René Panhard, Paris, France; LSCE, UMR 8212 CNRS/UVSQ.CEA, Orme des merisiers, Gif sur Yvette, France; Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Università di Firenze, via G. Broussonet, Montpellier, France, ISEM, UMR 5554 CNRS, Université Montpellier 2, Place Eugène Bataillon, Montpellier cedex 05, France; Klotz, S., Geographisches Institut, Universität Tübingen, Rümelinstr. 19-23, Tübingen, Germany; Montade, V., CBAE, UMR 5059 CNRS/EPHE/UM2/INRAP, Institut de Botanique, 163 rue A. Broussonet, Montpellier, France, ISEM, UMR 5554 CNRS, Université Montpellier 2, Place Eugène Bataillon, Montpellier cedex 05, France, Ecole Pratique des Hautes Etudes, EPHE, 4-14 rue Ferrus, Paris, France; Fauquette, S., ISEM, UMR 5554 CNRS, Université Montpellier 2, Place Eugène Bataillon, Montpellier cedex 05, France; Allen, J., School of Biological and Biomedical Sciences, Durham University, South Road, Durham, United Kingdom; Fusco, F., LIPPIA, Laboratorio Indipendente di Palinologia Paleontologica, Investigativa ed Ambientale, Viale G. Bovio 10, Pescara, Italy; Goring, S., Department of Geography, University of Wisconsin-MadisonWI, United States; Huntley, B., School of Biological and Biomedical Sciences, Durham University, South Road, Durham, United Kingdom; Joannin, Sé., CBAE, UMR 5059 CNRS/EPHE/UM2/INRAP, Institut de Botanique, 163 rue A. Broussonet, Montpellier, France, ISEM, UMR 5554 CNRS, Université Montpellier 2, Place Eugène Bataillon, Montpellier cedex 05, France, LGL. TPE, UMR 5276 CNRS, Université de Lyon1, 2 rue Dubois, Villeurbanne Cedex, France; Lebreton, V., HPNP, UMR 7194 CNRS, Département de Préhistoire du Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, 1 rue René Panhard, Paris, France; Magri, D., Dipartimento di Biologia Ambientale, Sapienza Università di Roma, P. le Aldo Moro 5, Roma, Italy; Martinetto, E., Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra Università degli Studi di Torino, Via Valperga Caluso 35, Torino, Italy; Orain, R., HPNP, UMR 7194 CNRS, Département de Préhistoire du Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, 1 rue René Panhard, Paris, France; Sadori, L., Dipartimento di Biologia Ambientale, Sapienza Università di Roma, P. le Aldo Moro 5, Roma, Italy","Pollen records and pollen-based climate reconstructions from the Italian peninsula (central Mediterranean) show clear signals of vegetation change linked to variations in water availability in the Mediterranean basin over the past 5. million. years. Profound vegetation changes occurred in four major steps from the Pliocene to the present. The subtropical taxa that dominate Pliocene assemblages declined and then disappeared between 3-2.8 and 1.66. Ma (at around 2.8. Ma in the North and later in the South), progressively being replaced by temperate Quercus forests at mid altitude. In the south Italy, Quercus expanded more at around 1.4-1.3. Ma and Fagus proportions increased after 0.5. Ma. Conifer forest (first mainly composed of Tsuga then by Abies and Picea) began to expand at 2.8. Ma, probably rather at high altitude, beginning at 2.8. Ma. Mediterranean-type forest, rare during the Early Pleistocene, developed and increased in diversity during the Middle Pleistocene. Open landscapes, with higher abundances of steppic taxa, became more frequent and extensive at the onset of Glacial/Interglacial (G/I) cyclicity around 2.6. Ma and gradually expanded with more and more marked glacials. Climate reconstructions done on selected pollen records from southern Italy suggest a decline in winter temperature and annual precipitation from the early Pleistocene to the Holocene. Specifically, both precipitation and winter temperature reconstructions show changes in interglacial maxima and glacial minima at around 3-2.8. Ma, 2. Ma, 1.3-1.4. Ma and 0.5. Ma.This critical review provides evidence that the North-South precipitation gradient, with drier conditions in the South, has been a consistent feature of the Italian peninsula since the beginning of the Pleistocene. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Central Mediterranean; Climate; Palynology; Pliocene; Quaternary; Vegetation,abundance; climate variation; coniferous forest; Mediterranean environment; paleoclimate; palynology; Pliocene; precipitation (climatology); Quaternary; subtropical region; vegetation dynamics; water availability; Italian Peninsula; Abies; Coniferophyta; Fagus; Picea; Quercus; Tsuga,,,,,"CNRS, Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique","Authors thank the CNRS for financial support. "Fauquette Sé., Bertini A., Manzi V., Roveri M., Argnani A., Menichetti E.",Reconstruction of the Northern and Central Apennines (Italy) palaeoaltitudes during the late Neogene from pollen data,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,117,126,,4,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2014.06.001,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937969230&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2014.06.001&partnerID=40&md5=8a6d268c17480d8df2c07a1e6e2a8057,"Institut des Sciences de l'Evolution (UM2-CNRS 5554), CC 061, Université de Montpellier 2, Place Eugène Bataillon, Montpellier cedex 5, France; Università degli Studi di Firenze, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Via G. La Pira 4, Firenze, Italy; Università degli Studi di Parma, Dipartimento di Fisica e Scienze della Terra, Parco Area delle Scienze 157/A, Parma, Italy; Istituto di Scienze Marine, ISMAR-CNR, Via Gobetti 101, Bologna, Italy","Fauquette, Sé., Institut des Sciences de l'Evolution (UM2-CNRS 5554), CC 061, Université de Montpellier 2, Place Eugène Bataillon, Montpellier cedex 5, France; Bertini, A., Università degli Studi di Firenze, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Via G. La Pira 4, Firenze, Italy; Manzi, V., Università degli Studi di Parma, Dipartimento di Fisica e Scienze della Terra, Parco Area delle Scienze 157/A, Parma, Italy; Roveri, M., Università degli Studi di Parma, Dipartimento di Fisica e Scienze della Terra, Parco Area delle Scienze 157/A, Parma, Italy; Argnani, A., Istituto di Scienze Marine, ISMAR-CNR, Via Gobetti 101, Bologna, Italy; Menichetti, E., Università degli Studi di Firenze, Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Via G. La Pira 4, Firenze, Italy","Palynological studies are considered as an excellent tool for palaeoaltitude estimates as sedimentary basins receive abundant pollen grains from surrounding uplands, especially through riverine detritic inputs. Here, we provide new evidence for estimating the palaeoaltitude of the Northern and Central Apennines (Italy) during the late Neogene (from the late Tortonian to the early Zanclean), based on vegetation data derived from pollen analysis of five sections (Trave, Legnagnone, Cava Li Monti, Maccarone and Stirone). The past vegetation changes reflect shifts in the vegetation belts on the nearby massifs. The climate reconstruction realised on these sites, at sea-level, suggests that mean annual temperatures were higher than today at the end of the Neogene. Therefore, the different vegetation belts occurred at higher elevation than at present to compensate for the higher temperatures. The results obtained in our study suggest that the Northern and Central Apennines were uplifted as early as the Tortonian attaining significant minimum altitudes around 1350. m up to 1500. m at the end of the Miocene in the Central part, a minimum altitude around 1900. m during the Messinian and around 2150. m during the early Zanclean in the Northern part. © 2014 Elsevier B.V.",Apennines; Messinian; Palaeoaltitudes; Pollen; Tortonian; Zanclean,Zanclea,,,,,"MIUR, Ministero dell’Istruzione, dell’Università e della Ricerca","Financial support: MIUR Grants to M. Roveri ( PRIN-COFIN 2003, 2006, 2008 ) and A. Bertini ( PRIN-COFIN 2006, 2008 ). We thank the 2 anonymous reviewers who help us to improve the manuscript. This paper is ISEM contribution n° 2014-088.","Argnani, A., The northern Apennines and the kinematics of Africa-Europe convergence (2002) Boll. Soc. Geol. Ital., (SPEC. 1), pp. 47-60; Argnani, A., Plate motion and the evolution of Alpine Corsica and Northern Apennines (2012) Tectonophysics, 579, pp. 207-219; Argnani, A., Ricci Lucchi, F., Tertiary siliciclastic turbidite systems of the Northern Apennines (2001) Anatomy of a Mountain: The Apennines and Adjacent Mediterranean Basins, pp. 327-350. , Kluwer Academic Publisher, London, G.B. "Russo Ermolli E., Di Donato V., Martín-Fernández J.A., Orain R., Lebreton V., Piovesan G.",Vegetation patterns in the Southern Apennines (Italy) during MIS 13: Deciphering pollen variability along a NW-SE transect,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,167,183,,6,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2014.11.004,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84988239935&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2014.11.004&partnerID=40&md5=5f81e8b6c1ea5fd0fc6a69275f816ec6,"Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Dell'Ambiente e delle Risorse (DiSTAR), Università di Napoli Federico II, Largo San Marcellino 10, Napoli, Italy; Departament d'Informàtica, Matemàtica Aplicada i Estadística, Universitat de Girona, Edifici P4 Campus Montilivi, Girona, Spain; Département de Préhistoire UMR7194, Muséum National Histoire Naturelle, 1 rue R. Panhard, Paris, France; Dipartimento di Scienze e Tecnologie per l'Agricoltura, Le Foreste, La Natura e l'Energia (DAFNE), Università della Tuscia, Via San Camillo de Lellis s.n.c., Viterbo, Italy","Russo Ermolli, E., Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Dell'Ambiente e delle Risorse (DiSTAR), Università di Napoli Federico II, Largo San Marcellino 10, Napoli, Italy, Département de Préhistoire UMR7194, Muséum National Histoire Naturelle, 1 rue R. Panhard, Paris, France; Di Donato, V., Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Dell'Ambiente e delle Risorse (DiSTAR), Università di Napoli Federico II, Largo San Marcellino 10, Napoli, Italy; Martín-Fernández, J.A., Departament d'Informàtica, Matemàtica Aplicada i Estadística, Universitat de Girona, Edifici P4 Campus Montilivi, Girona, Spain; Orain, R., Département de Préhistoire UMR7194, Muséum National Histoire Naturelle, 1 rue R. Panhard, Paris, France; Lebreton, V., Département de Préhistoire UMR7194, Muséum National Histoire Naturelle, 1 rue R. Panhard, Paris, France; Piovesan, G., Dipartimento di Scienze e Tecnologie per l'Agricoltura, Le Foreste, La Natura e l'Energia (DAFNE), Università della Tuscia, Via San Camillo de Lellis s.n.c., Viterbo, Italy","Pollen data from five palaeo-lacustrine basins are used in this study to correlate floral and vegetation patterns along a NW-SE transect in the Southern Apennines (Italy) during Marine Isotope Stage (MIS) 13. Compositional Data Analysis (CoDA) is applied to pollen data in order to better define and explain the main differences in the pollen composition of coeval records. Pollen data belonging to MIS 13, chosen on the basis of a constrained cluster analysis on each entire record, have been analyzed through a non-constrained cluster analysis. The relative variation biplot, the parametric and the non-parametric MANOVA computed for the MIS 13 pollen data, show that samples belonging to the different sites are distinct by their average composition. This means that each site has a distinctive character of forest landscape, which could have been the result of local environmental (physical) factors, such as mesoclimate, topography and edaphic humidity, and/or of historical factors such as species composition of refuges and temporary changes in environmental conditions due to disturbance ecology. © 2014 Elsevier B.V.",Abies; Compositional Data Analysis; Fagus; Middle Pleistocene; Relative variation biplot; Vegetation dynamic,cluster analysis; correlation; environmental disturbance; forest floor; lacustrine environment; marine isotope stage; paleoenvironment; palynology; transect; vegetation dynamics; Apennines; Italy; Abies; Fagus,,,,,MTM2012-33236,This research has been supported by the Spanish Ministry of Economy and Competitiveness under the project “METRICS” Ref. MTM2012-33236 . Archaeobotany, 15 (4), pp. 435-444","Russo Ermolli, E.; Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Dell'Ambiente e delle Risorse (DiSTAR), Università di Napoli Federico II, Largo San Marcellino 10, Italy",,,Elsevier Inc.,,,,,346667,,RPPYA,,English,Rev. Palaeobot. Palynol.,Article,,Scopus,2-s2.0-84988239935,,,,,,,
"Magri D., Agrillo E., Di Rita F., Furlanetto G., Pini R., Ravazzi C., Spada F.",Holocene dynamics of tree taxa populations in Italy,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,267,284,,17,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2014.08.012,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937932336&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2014.08.012&partnerID=40&md5=1a94b838eee396b7d3c3c5d11b57ed5c,"Department of Environmental Biology, Sapienza University, Piazzale Aldo Moro, 5, Roma, Italy; CNR - Institute for the Dynamics of Environmental Processes, Laboratory of Palynology and Palaeoecology, Piazza della Scienza 1, Milano, Italy","Magri, D., Department of Environmental Biology, Sapienza University, Piazzale Aldo Moro, 5, Roma, Italy; Agrillo, E., Department of Environmental Biology, Sapienza University, Piazzale Aldo Moro, 5, Roma, Italy; Di Rita, F., Department of Environmental Biology, Sapienza University, Piazzale Aldo Moro, 5, Roma, Italy; Furlanetto, G., CNR - Institute for the Dynamics of Environmental Processes, Laboratory of Palynology and Palaeoecology, Piazza della Scienza 1, Milano, Italy; Pini, R., CNR - Institute for the Dynamics of Environmental Processes, Laboratory of Palynology and Palaeoecology, Piazza della Scienza 1, Milano, Italy; Ravazzi, C., CNR - Institute for the Dynamics of Environmental Processes, Laboratory of Palynology and Palaeoecology, Piazza della Scienza 1, Milano, Italy; Spada, F., Department of Environmental Biology, Sapienza University, Piazzale Aldo Moro, 5, Roma, Italy","The Holocene distribution of nine tree taxa (Picea, Abies, Betula, Fagus, Carpinus betulus, Corylus, deciduous and evergreen Quercus, and Olea) in Italy is visually shown by pollen maps. A hundred pollen sites were selected, percentages were derived from the original pollen counts or digitized from published diagrams, and represented on maps in subsequent time windows at 1000-year intervals. The pollen maps depict the Holocene history of Italian forest cover as a complex puzzle influenced by very diverse climate, physiography, edaphic and ecological processes, and a long history of human activity.A reasonably good match between the abundance and distribution of pollen data during the last thousand years and the current tree species distribution in Italy indicates that the Holocene pollen maps may represent a fundamental basis for a better understanding of the modern vegetation patterns, often showing discontinuous ranges and complex distributions. Although clear latitudinal gradients were not detected, regions characterized by high precipitation values hosted dense forest cover since the Holocene onset, while areas with arid climate experienced a delayed increase in trees and a faster decrease during the last four millennia. Fagus, C. betulus and Picea show displacement in their distribution in Italy in the course of the Holocene. Other taxa, like deciduous and evergreen Quercus, and Betula have always occupied the same locations during the Holocene, but show changes in abundance. Abies had a broken distribution in Italy throughout the postglacial. Its populations are currently found within the regions they occupied at the onset of the Holocene. The importance of considering all the available records in their geographical context to reconstruct complex vegetational patterns is discussed. © 2014 Elsevier B.V.",Database; Holocene; Italy; Pollen map; Woody taxon,abundance; database; environmental history; evergreen tree; forest cover; gradient analysis; Holocene; human activity; palynology; population distribution; vegetation cover; woody plant; Italy; Abies; Betula; Carpinus betulus; Corylus; Fagus; Picea; Picea abies; Quercus,,,,,,"This work was partly carried out in the frame of the CNR-DTA NextData Project. We thank Fabio Attorre for providing the modern precipitation map, Francesco Di Domenico for his help in collecting pollen data from published records and Josu Aranbarri for his helpful suggestions. "Fiorentino G., Parra I.","""Lost"" postglacial littoral environments in SE Italy: Anthracological evidence at Grotta delle Mura",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,198,203,,,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2014.05.009,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937969087&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2014.05.009&partnerID=40&md5=d4f93388a80c11551417cdef7ee8aba4,"Laboratorio di Archeobotanica e Paleoecologia, Università del Salento, Via D. Birago, 64, Lecce, Italy; Observatorio Impactos Climaticos Levante Almeriense OBAL-LEAL, C/Cervantes 37, 212 P.B., Garrucha, Spain; Agustinas 1569 Depto 54, Santiago de Chile, Chile","Fiorentino, G., Laboratorio di Archeobotanica e Paleoecologia, Università del Salento, Via D. Birago, 64, Lecce, Italy; Parra, I., Observatorio Impactos Climaticos Levante Almeriense OBAL-LEAL, C/Cervantes 37, 212 P.B., Garrucha, Spain, Agustinas 1569 Depto 54, Santiago de Chile, Chile","Research on charcoal remains from prehistoric caves located in the south Adriatic-Sea coast reveals the regional palaeovegetation composition and its strong relationship to rapid changes of the eustatic sea level, during the last glacial-interglacial cycle and early Holocene. We intend to characterize biogeographical conditions mechanically disturbed by the glacial-interglacial transgressive eustatic level, which destroyed the trees and shrubs managed by prehistoric Adriatic human populations. Thus it appears that some ligneous taxa, such as deciduous taxa (Quercus, Prunoideae, etc.) and the genus Pistacia, may be considered markers of the rapid eustatic changes within this littoral environment. © 2014 Elsevier B.V.",Adriatic Sea; Anthracology; Holocene; Palaeobiogeography; Palaeolithic-Mesolithic caves; Upper Pleistocene,Pistacia; Quercus,,,,,,Foundation G. Obrien in Edinburgh sustained GF and IP during the first period of this research (grant no. 107 ). Programme 05 -11 Mediterranean landscape origins of OBAL-LEAL funded IP (grant no. 112 ). GF wishes to thank Mauro Calattini for the widespread availability in the study of material recovered during the excavations at GdM and the useful and stimulating discussions. Donatella Magri sustained the long range research effort of our inquiry with productive criticism and material support at her Laboratory in Rome. "Trincianti E., Frixa A., Sartorio D.",Palynology and stratigraphic characterization of subsurface sedimentary successions in the Sicanian and Imerese Domains-Central Western Sicily,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,48,66,,2,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.01.006,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937974655&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.01.006&partnerID=40&md5=35a1a339b33df044286a28b901b53b6a,"Eni S.p.A Upstream and Technical Services, Via Emilia 1, San Donato Milanese, Milan, Italy","Trincianti, E., Eni S.p.A Upstream and Technical Services, Via Emilia 1, San Donato Milanese, Milan, Italy; Frixa, A., Eni S.p.A Upstream and Technical Services, Via Emilia 1, San Donato Milanese, Milan, Italy; Sartorio, D., Eni S.p.A Upstream and Technical Services, Via Emilia 1, San Donato Milanese, Milan, Italy","According to past publications, the deep-water Mesozoic successions that outcrop in the Sicilian chain area belong to different stratigraphic-structural domains: the Sicanian and Imerese thrust systems. These were investigated in the subsurface by means of many wells, most of which were drilled in the 1960s.The two domains share a common basement represented by the Lercara Complex (Permian-Ladinian), the Mufara Formation (Carnian) and the Scillato Formation (Upper Carnian-Rhaetian).Palynological studies carried out by Eni S.p.A. on exploration wells such as Creta 1 and Platani 2 allowed a better stratigraphic characterization of the Upper Triassic Mufara and Scillato formations. Well Casteltermini 1, drilled by Eni S.p.A. in 2009, crossed a system of two superposed tectonic nappes and reached the deep Permo-Triassic basement composed by the Lercara Complex and the Mufara Formation. The palynological analysis performed on these successions, indicates that the Lercara Complex is composed of at least four units. The lower unit is Permian in age, ranging from a questionable 'mid Artinskian-Kungurian' to Roadian-early Wordian. It is followed by a second thinner unit dated late Wordian-Capitanian. Above this Permian well section a third lithologically well defined unit of indeterminate age was encountered. An uppermost and fourth unit yielded Ladinian microfloras and was kept distinct from the overlying Mufara Formation of early-late Carnian age. The Lercara Complex and the Mufara Formation are overlain by the lower-middle Eocene Scaglia-type sediments (Amerillo Formation) by means of a tectonic contact.The age constraint provided by palynology and the accurate lithostratigraphic characterization of the Middle Permian to Middle Triassic Lercara Complex, intersected by well Casteltermini 1, suggest several and significant similarities with the Sosio Valley sediments outcropping near to Palazzo Adriano. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Permian-Triassic; Pollen; Spores; Stratigraphy; Subsurface/outcrop correlation; Western Sicily (Italy),basement (building); biostratigraphy; exploration; lithology; lithostratigraphy; outcrop; palynology; Permian-Triassic boundary; spore; succession; thrust; Italy; Sicily,,,,,,,"Adloff, M.C., Doubinger, J., Massa, D., Vachard, D., Trias de Tripolitaine (Libye). "Spina A., Cirilli S., Utting J., Jansonius J.","Palynology of the Permian and Triassic of the Tesero and Bulla sections (Western Dolomites, Italy) and consideration about the enigmatic species Reduviasporonites chalastus",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,3,14,,7,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2014.10.003,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937862417&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2014.10.003&partnerID=40&md5=77f4e18b4e8e57bfa5fdd075bd37d5e2,"Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, Università di Perugia, Via Pascoli, Perugia, Italy; Geological Survey of Canada (Calgary), 3303 33rd St, N.W. Calgary, AB, Canada","Spina, A., Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, Università di Perugia, Via Pascoli, Perugia, Italy; Cirilli, S., Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, Università di Perugia, Via Pascoli, Perugia, Italy; Utting, J., Geological Survey of Canada (Calgary), 3303 33rd St, N.W. Calgary, AB, Canada; Jansonius, J.","A palynological study of two Permian-Triassic sections of the Southern Alps (Tesero and Bulla sections) was carried out in order to correlate the palynological data with the available conodont zones. Both the sections crop out in the Western Dolomites, the Tesero section in Fiemme Valley and the Bulla section in Badia valley.The two sections include the uppermost Bellerophon Formation and the overlying Werfen Formation. In the latter the Permian/Triassic boundary (Farabegoli et al., 2007) has been defined by conodonts. The palynological assemblages collected in both sections throughout the Bellerophon up to the Werfen formations show compositional variation marked by: a) a dominance of taeniate and non-taeniate bisaccates in the Bellerophon Formation dated as Late Permian; b) a bloom of the organic microfossil incertae sedis Reduviasporonites chalastus in the lower Tesero Member (Werfen Formation), found only in the Tesero section. This interval should stratigraphically lie below the Permian/Triassic boundary, as defined by conodonts recorded in the Bulla section; c) poorly preserved acavate and bisaccate taxa in the upper Tesero Member, above the Permian/Triassic boundary, and in the overlying Mazzin Member of the Tesero section. The origin and the ecological preferences of Reduviasporonites chalastus and the implications of its worldwide distribution across the Permian/Triassic boundary are also discussed. © 2014 Elsevier B.V.",Bulla section; Italy; Permian-Triassic boundary; Reduviasporonites chalastus; Tesero section; Western Dolomites,biostratigraphy; conodont; dominance; green alga; paleobotany; palynology; Permian-Triassic boundary; Dolomites; Eastern Alps; Italy; Bellerophon,,,,,,,"Afonin, S.A., Barinova, S.S., Krassilov, V.A., A bloom of Tympanicysta Balme (green algae of zygnematalean affinities) at the Permian-Triassic boundary (2001) Geodiversitas, 23, pp. 481-487; Assereto, R., Bosellini, A., Fantini Sestini, N., Sweet, W.C., The Permian-Triassic boundary in Southern Alps (Italy) (1973) Canadian Society of Petroleum Geologists Memoir, 2, pp. 176-199; Balme, B.E., Palynology of Permian and Triassic strata in the Salt Range and Surghar Range, West Pakistan (1970) University Press of Kansas, Department of Geology Special Publication, 4, pp. 305-453. , B. "Ricci M., Bertini A., Capezzuoli E., Horvatinčić N., Andrews J.E., Fauquette S., Fedi M.","Palynological investigation of a Late Quaternary calcareous tufa and travertine deposit: The case study of Bagnoli in the Valdelsa Basin (Tuscany, central Italy)",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,218,,,184,197,,4,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2014.10.004,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937917611&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2014.10.004&partnerID=40&md5=b089bbdb4fcbe0b92a33dcca57c10162,"Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Università di Firenze, via G. La Pira 4, Firenze, Italy; CNR-Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, IGG-Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse, via G. La Pira 4, Firenze, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, via Pascoli, Perugia, Italy; Rudjer Bošković Institute, Bijenička 54, Zagreb, Croatia; School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom; Institut des Sciences de l'Evolution (UM2-CNRS 5554), Université de Montpellier 2, CC 061, Place Eugène Bataillon, Montpellier cedex 5, France; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Firenze, via Sansone 1, Sesto Fiorentino, Firenze, Italy","Ricci, M., Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Università di Firenze, via G. La Pira 4, Firenze, Italy; Bertini, A., Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra, Università di Firenze, via G. La Pira 4, Firenze, Italy, CNR-Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, IGG-Istituto di Geoscienze e Georisorse, via G. La Pira 4, Firenze, Italy; Capezzuoli, E., Dipartimento di Fisica e Geologia, via Pascoli, Perugia, Italy; Horvatinčić, N., Rudjer Bošković Institute, Bijenička 54, Zagreb, Croatia; Andrews, J.E., School of Environmental Sciences, University of East Anglia, Norwich, United Kingdom; Fauquette, S., Institut des Sciences de l'Evolution (UM2-CNRS 5554), Université de Montpellier 2, CC 061, Place Eugène Bataillon, Montpellier cedex 5, France; Fedi, M., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Firenze, via Sansone 1, Sesto Fiorentino, Firenze, Italy","A Late Quaternary continental succession in central Italy (Bagnoli, Valdelsa Basin) which includes terrigenous and carbonate (calcareous tufa and travertine) sediments was investigated with palynology, 14C dating and stable isotopic techniques. Pollen analyses of 43 samples, including quantification by the Climate Amplitude Method, allowed the documentation of the main palaeoenvironmental, vegetational and climatic changes. Taphonomic biases related to the depositional settings are expressed by i) the significant occurrence of Pinus related to the increase of riverine input/waterborne pollen components in the basal terrigenous strata and by ii) the generally significant presence of herbs, testimony to the local pollen input and dominance of the airborne pollen component in calcareous tufa and travertine. 14C dating on organic samples confirms the Late Quaternary age of the section and the pollen record supports evidence for the onset of carbonate deposition during the Late Glacial Interstadial (LGI), coincident with expansion of thermophilous tree taxa, especially deciduous oaks. Successive cool and dry climate events are attested by the contemporaneous decrease of broad leaved deciduous forest taxa and a rise in herbs. Major unconformities as well as erosional, non-depositional or dissolution events, which interrupt the carbonate deposition at different times in the sequence, are interpreted as a direct response to global climate change and associated to cooler events (i.e. GS-2, GS-1, colder episodes during the LGI). As a whole δ13C and δ18O records do not show any clear relationship to the pollen-derived climatic data or to the carbonate units; rather they reflect a mixing of superficial CO<inf>2</inf> and a deeper source, underlining the complex origin of the Bagnoli carbonates. © 2014 Elsevier B.V.",Italy; Late Quaternary; Palaeoenvironment; Pollen; Stable isotope; Terrestrial carbonate,calcareous soil; carbonate sediment; climate variation; global climate; isotopic analysis; paleoenvironment; palynology; Quaternary; radiocarbon dating; taphonomy; travertine; tufa; Italy; Tuscany; Valdelsa Basin; Quercus,,,,,"098-0982709-2741; Ministry of Education and Science, Republic of Latvia; UEA, University of East Anglia","The research was financially supported by: A.UNIFI.D.58517.GGSGP.CR03.BERTITEN10 and 11 Grants to A. "Heinrichs J., Schmidt A.R., Schäfer-Verwimp A., Gröhn C., Renner M.A.M.",The leafy liverwort Notoscyphus balticus sp. nov. (Jungermanniales) in Eocene Baltic amber,2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,217,,,39,44,,7,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.02.006,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84935038011&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.02.006&partnerID=40&md5=76df098e76fd99ecdbc08dcd60c4b32a,"Department für Biologie I, Systematische Botanik und Mykologie, Geobio-Center, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Menzinger Straße 67, München, Germany; Abteilung Geobiologie, Georg-August-Universität Göttingen, Goldschmidtstraße 3, Göttingen, Germany; Mittlere Letten 11, Herdwangen-Schönach, Germany; Amber Study Group, C/o Geological-Palaeontological Institute, Museum of the University of Hamburg, Bundesstraße 55, Hamburg, Germany; Royal Botanic Gardens and Domain Trust, Mrs Macquaries Road, Sydney, NSW, Australia","Heinrichs, J., Department für Biologie I, Systematische Botanik und Mykologie, Geobio-Center, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München, Menzinger Straße 67, München, Germany; Schmidt, A.R., Abteilung Geobiologie, Georg-August-Universität Göttingen, Goldschmidtstraße 3, Göttingen, Germany; Schäfer-Verwimp, A., Mittlere Letten 11, Herdwangen-Schönach, Germany; Gröhn, C., Amber Study Group, C/o Geological-Palaeontological Institute, Museum of the University of Hamburg, Bundesstraße 55, Hamburg, Germany; Renner, M.A.M., Royal Botanic Gardens and Domain Trust, Mrs Macquaries Road, Sydney, NSW, Australia","We describe a sterile gametophyte fragment of a leafy liverwort in a piece of Eocene Baltic amber possessing clustered rhizoids, succubously inserted, alternating, entire leaves, papillose stem and lamina cells, and bifid underleaves not coadunate to the leaves. The fossil is assigned to the extant genus Notoscyphus and treated as Notoscyphus balticus sp. nov. It differs from extant representatives of Notoscyphus by its uniformly brown colour, rhizoids with a diameter of 15-23. μm and small leaf cells (ca. 17-25. μm. ×. 17-30. μm at midpoint). Putative septate rhizoids of the fossil are more likely unicellular rhizoids covered with thin fungal hyphae that can easily be confused with septa. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Classification; Fossil; Jungermanniineae; Jungermanniopsida; Marchantiophyta; Rhizoids,,,,,,,,"Ander, K., (1942) Die Insektenfauna des baltischen Bernsteins nebst damit verknüpften zoogeographischen Problemen, , Lund, Gleerup; Bakalin, V., Vilnet, A.A., Two new species of the liverwort genus Hygrobiella Spruce (Marchantiophyta) described from the North Pacific based on integrative taxonomy (2014) Plant Syst. "Torrescano-Valle N., Islebe G.A.","Holocene paleoecology, climate history and human influence in the southwestern Yucatan Peninsula",2015,Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology,217,,,1,8,,9,10.1016/j.revpalbo.2015.03.003,https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.uri?eid=2-s2.0-84937758104&doi=10.1016%2fj.revpalbo.2015.03.003&partnerID=40&md5=08688ef6579af42fa5450b6ed5dc30b0,"El Colegio de la Frontera Sur, Unidad Chetumal, Avenida Centenario km 5.5, AP 424, CP 77014, Chetumal, Quintana Roo, Mexico","Torrescano-Valle, N., El Colegio de la Frontera Sur, Unidad Chetumal, Avenida Centenario km 5.5, AP 424, CP 77014, Chetumal, Quintana Roo, Mexico; Islebe, G.A., El Colegio de la Frontera Sur, Unidad Chetumal, Avenida Centenario km 5.5, AP 424, CP 77014, Chetumal, Quintana Roo, Mexico","Centennial resolution pollen analysis of a record from Lake Silvituc, Yucatan Peninsula, provides a 7900. cal. yr BP record of vegetation history and climate change in the Maya lowlands. Several droughts occurred during this interval, some of which are evident in other paleoclimatic records from the Caribbean region. We identified taxa that are characteristic of paleoecological change, such as Moraceae, Ficus and Asteraceae, among others. Zea mays and other taxa reflect the Maya occupation and its impact on the landscape. Droughts, as inferred from vegetational and sedimentary changes, occurred during the intervals of 4700-3600. cal. yr BP, 3400-2500. cal. yr BP, 2300-2100. cal. yr BP, 1900-1700. cal. yr BP, 1400-1300. cal. yr BP, 730. cal. yr BP and 560. cal. yr BP. During these periods, tropical forest taxa elements declined (Moraceae, Brosimum alicastrum, Ficus and Fabaceae) and secondary elements increased (Asteraceae, Mimosoidae-. Acacia, Chenopodiaceae Vent. and Poaceae), as did local aquatic elements (. Botryococcus). Zea mays appeared 4100. cal. yr BP, and other secondary elements, such as Asteraceae, Mimosoideae-. Acacia, and Chenopodiaceae Vent, increased. The Preclassic abandonment is represented in the record as a shift to drier conditions and a strong decrease in forest taxa. © 2015 Elsevier B.V.",Late Holocene; Maya lowland; Paleoecology; Pollen; Yucatan Peninsula,,,,,,"N127613, CONACYT, Consejo Nacional de Ciencia y Tecnología; N25035, CONACYT, Consejo Nacional de Ciencia y Tecnología","CONACYT is acknowledged for their financial support of projects N25035 , “ Reconstrucciones paleoclimáticas y paleoecológicas del Holoceno Tardío de Quintana Roo ,” and N127613 , “ Variabilidad climática y paleoecología de los últimos 1500 años del sureste de México ”.
